item.title: Four doctors houses under construction at Tambul Station
item.description:
Four new residential houses for doctors are currently under construction at Tambul Station, in a move aimed at improving accommodation and working conditions for medical professionals serving the area.

The project is being implemented under the leadership of local Member of Parliament, Win Bakri Daki, as part of broader efforts to strengthen healthcare services in Tambul and surrounding communities.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Four doctors houses under construction at Tambul Station appeared first on Post Courier.
item.source:markdown:

Four new residential houses for doctors are currently under construction at Tambul Station, in a move aimed at improving accommodation and working conditions for medical professionals serving the area.
The project is being implemented under the leadership of local Member of Parliament, Win Bakri Daki, as part of broader efforts to strengthen healthcare services in Tambul and surrounding communities.

item.title: Kerema to host Papua LNG Forum despite landowner objections
item.description:
Kerema Town has been confirmed as the host venue for the upcoming Papua LNG Development Forum, despite calls from some landowners for the meeting to be relocated to Port Moresby over safety and health concerns.

Member for Kerema and Minister for Finance Thomas Opa has assured all stakeholders that comprehensive planning and resourcing are already in place to ensure the successful hosting of the nationally significant forum.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Kerema to host Papua LNG Forum despite landowner objections appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: US strike on Venezuela to embolden China’s territorial claims: analysts
item.description: President Donald Trump's audacious attack, capturing Venezuelan leader Nicolas Maduro, hands China an unexpected opportunity that Beijing will likely use in the near term to amplify criticism of Washington and bolster its own standing on the international stage, analysts say

item.title: Trump says U.S. will run Venezuela after U.S. captures Maduro
item.description: WASHINGTON (Reuters) — U.S. President Donald Trump said ​on Saturday he was putting Venezuela under temporary American control after ‌the United States captured President Nicolas Maduro in an audacious raid and whisked him to New York to face drug-trafficking charges.
item.source:markdown: WASHINGTON (Reuters) — U.S. President Donald Trump said ​on Saturday he was putting Venezuela under temporary American control after ‌the United States captured President Nicolas Maduro in an audacious raid and whisked him to New York to face drug-trafficking charges.

item.title: Democrats raise alarms after Trump avoids congressional approval for Maduro’s capture
item.description: WASHINGTON — Republicans in Congress on Saturday cheered the Trump administration’s dramatic military action to capture President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela, but top Democrats sounded alarms about the legality of the operation and said they would seek a quick vote to halt hostilities without express authorization.
item.source:markdown: WASHINGTON — Republicans in Congress on Saturday cheered the Trump administration’s dramatic military action to capture President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela, but top Democrats sounded alarms about the legality of the operation and said they would seek a quick vote to halt hostilities without express authorization.

item.title: Managers of Swiss bar are suspected of negligence in deadly fire, police say
item.description: CRANS-MONTANA, Switzerland — The two managers of a bar in the Swiss Alps where at least 40 people died in a sudden fire early New Year’s Day have been placed under criminal investigation because of allegations of negligence, police said Saturday, as authorities in Switzerland come under growing pressure to explain whether flaws in the site’s design and management fueled the disaster.
item.source:markdown: CRANS-MONTANA, Switzerland — The two managers of a bar in the Swiss Alps where at least 40 people died in a sudden fire early New Year’s Day have been placed under criminal investigation because of allegations of negligence, police said Saturday, as authorities in Switzerland come under growing pressure to explain whether flaws in the site’s design and management fueled the disaster.

item.description: WASHINGTON — President Donald Trump raised the taxes that the United States charges on imports last year to levels not seen in a century.

item.title: Airlines canceling flights after the US closes Caribbean airspace
item.description: U.S. airlines canceled flights, and air travel was disrupted Saturday after federal aviation authorities shut down U.S.-controlled airspace over the Caribbean in response to a U.S. military operation in Venezuela that resulted in the capture of the country’s president.
item.source:markdown: U.S. airlines canceled flights, and air travel was disrupted Saturday after federal aviation authorities shut down U.S.-controlled airspace over the Caribbean in response to a U.S. military operation in Venezuela that resulted in the capture of the country’s president.

item.title: Obituaries for January 4
item.description: Marciana Ogoc Estencion, 77, of Kailua-Kona died, Dec. 4 at Kona Community Hospital. Born in Kealakekua, she was a stock clerk for the former KMart and delivered newspapers for West Hawaii Today. Visitation 8:30-10 a.m. Friday, Jan. 23, at St. John’s Catholic Church in Kealakekua. Mass at 10 a.m. Burial to follow at Kona Memorial Park in Holualoa. Casual attire. Survived by son, James Mark (Roslyn) Thomas of Kona; stepchildren, Yolanda (Rick) Bautista of Honolulu, Alfred Estencion of Kona, Darren Estencion of Maui and Eldaine Barawis of Kailua-Kona; godchildren, Casey Keohuloa, Pikake Keohuloa and Trina Kauhaihao; three grandchildren; nieces, nephews, and cousins. Arrangements by Dodo Mortuary.
item.source:markdown: Marciana Ogoc Estencion, 77, of Kailua-Kona died, Dec. 4 at Kona Community Hospital. Born in Kealakekua, she was a stock clerk for the former KMart and delivered newspapers for West Hawaii Today. Visitation 8:30-10 a.m. Friday, Jan. 23, at St. John’s Catholic Church in Kealakekua. Mass at 10 a.m. Burial to follow at Kona Memorial Park in Holualoa. Casual attire. Survived by son, James Mark (Roslyn) Thomas of Kona; stepchildren, Yolanda (Rick) Bautista of Honolulu, Alfred Estencion of Kona, Darren Estencion of Maui and Eldaine Barawis of Kailua-Kona; godchildren, Casey Keohuloa, Pikake Keohuloa and Trina Kauhaihao; three grandchildren; nieces, nephews, and cousins. Arrangements by Dodo Mortuary.

item.title: Shock and skepticism in world’s capitals after US seizes Maduro
item.description: BERLIN — Despite the long military buildup around Venezuela, the U.S. raid on Caracas, the capital, to capture President Nicolás Maduro and his wife produced initial reactions of shock, outrage and skepticism from international leaders, many of them troubled by an exercise of U.S. gunboat diplomacy.
item.source:markdown: BERLIN — Despite the long military buildup around Venezuela, the U.S. raid on Caracas, the capital, to capture President Nicolás Maduro and his wife produced initial reactions of shock, outrage and skepticism from international leaders, many of them troubled by an exercise of U.S. gunboat diplomacy.

item.title: Venezuelan official says at least 40 people were killed in US attack
item.description: (NYT) — At least 40 people were killed in the U.S. attack on Venezuela early Saturday, including military personnel and civilians, according to a senior Venezuelan official who spoke on the condition of anonymity to describe preliminary reports.
item.source:markdown: (NYT) — At least 40 people were killed in the U.S. attack on Venezuela early Saturday, including military personnel and civilians, according to a senior Venezuelan official who spoke on the condition of anonymity to describe preliminary reports.

item.title: Trump administration declines to back Venezuela’s opposition leader
item.description: President Donald Trump said Saturday that it would be “very tough” for Venezuela’s leading opposition figure, María Corina Machado, to take control of her country, claiming in his televised speech that she was a “very nice woman” but “doesn’t have the support” in Venezuela to lead.

item.title: Steves: Gibraltar is a bite of Britain in Spain
item.description: When in southern Spain, I can’t resist popping into the British colony of Gibraltar. Gibraltar is hardly signposted in Spain, as if Spain wishes the British colony didn’t exist. (Drivers follow highway signs to La Línea, the last Spanish town before the border.) But when you see that famous “Rock of Prudential” standing boldly above the sea, you know it’s here to stay.
item.source:markdown: When in southern Spain, I can’t resist popping into the British colony of Gibraltar. Gibraltar is hardly signposted in Spain, as if Spain wishes the British colony didn’t exist. (Drivers follow highway signs to La Línea, the last Spanish town before the border.) But when you see that famous “Rock of Prudential” standing boldly above the sea, you know it’s here to stay.

item.title: Madang reconnected to Ramu Grid after heroic effort by PNG Power Crews
item.description:
Residents of Madang are finally back on the grid following a grueling restoration effort by PNG Power Limited (PPL) teams who battled extreme weather conditions to repair the L605 transmission line.

The coastal town had been split from the main Ramu grid after heavy rains and severe flooding at the Assas bypass triggered a major system fault.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Madang reconnected to Ramu Grid after heroic effort by PNG Power Crews appeared first on Post Courier.
item.source:markdown:
![](https://www.postcourier.com.pg/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/PPL-Officer-Graham-Jones-clearing-the-tree-on-the-line-that-was-brought-down-yesterday-by-the-heavy-rain.png?w=800)
Residents of Madang are finally back on the grid following a grueling restoration effort by PNG Power Limited (PPL) teams who battled extreme weather conditions to repair the L605 transmission line.

item.title: Major power failure plunges Highlands hubs into darkness
item.description:
A major fault on the main 66kV transmission line has left thousands of residents and businesses across the Highlands region without power, as PNG Power Limited (PPL) scrambles to stabilize the Ramu Grid.

The disruption occurred after Transmission Line 506, the primary link carrying electricity from Ramu through Goroka to the Highlands, tripped off. The outage has affected several provincial hubs, including: Kainantu, Goroka, Kundiawa, Kudjip, Mt. Hagen

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Major power failure plunges Highlands hubs into darkness appeared first on Post Courier.
item.source:markdown:
![](https://www.postcourier.com.pg/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/PNG-Power-Limited-PPL-scrambles-to-stabilize-the-Ramu-Grid.-FILE-PHOTOS.png?w=800)
A major fault on the main 66kV transmission line has left thousands of residents and businesses across the Highlands region without power, as PNG Power Limited (PPL) scrambles to stabilize the Ramu Grid.
The disruption occurred after **Transmission Line 506**, the primary link carrying electricity from Ramu through Goroka to the Highlands, tripped off. The outage has affected several provincial hubs, including: _Kainantu, Goroka, Kundiawa, Kudjip, Mt. Hagen_

item.title: Central Provincial Government moves to protect rural producers from market harassment
item.description:
The Central Provincial Government (CPG), led by Deputy Governor and Chairman for Law & Order, Desmond Baira, is initiating high-level meetings to address the systemic harassment of rural producers supplying the National Capital District (NCD).

Farmers, fishermen, and betelnut growers from Central Province report growing intimidation and extortion when transporting goods to major NCD hubs, including Gordons, Boroko, and Koki. A primary concern is the predatory behaviour of "middlemen" who demand unauthorised "carrying fees."

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Central Provincial Government moves to protect rural producers from market harassment appeared first on Post Courier.
item.source:markdown:
![](https://www.postcourier.com.pg/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/Central-Provincial-Government-moves-to-protect-rural-producers-from-market-harassment.png?w=800)
The Central Provincial Government (CPG), led by Deputy Governor and Chairman for Law & Order, Desmond Baira, is initiating high-level meetings to address the systemic harassment of rural producers supplying the National Capital District (NCD).
Farmers, fishermen, and betelnut growers from Central Province report growing intimidation and extortion when transporting goods to major NCD hubs, including Gordons, Boroko, and Koki. A primary concern is the predatory behaviour of "middlemen" who demand unauthorised "carrying fees."

item.title: North Carolina man accused of planning potential terrorist attack
item.description: In the final days of 2025, Christian Sturdivant, a teenager in North Carolina, struck up a conversation online with someone claiming to be a follower of the Islamic State terrorist organization. Sturdivant, federal investigators said, then revealed details of a possible attack. He shared a photo showing a knife and hammers. He asked for help getting guns. And he declared his devotion to the cause and his willingness to die for it.

item.title: A study is retracted, renewing concerns about the weedkiller Roundup
item.description: In 2000, a landmark study claimed to set the record straight on glyphosate, a contentious weedkiller used on hundreds of millions of acres of farmland. item.description:
By ELIZABETH PINJWAI MAKIS

The revival of Touch Rugby in West New Britain Province (WNBP) has reached a turning point this week with the hosting of the inaugural Mayor’s Cup touch tournament. The tournament, which launched on Christmas Day, is being hailed as a critical "restart" for a sport that has remained largely dormant in the province for a decade.

item.title: Bookshelf: The golden age of Oceania writing: Linking Indigenous literatures to modernism
item.description: In the 1960s and 1970s, the University of Papua New Guinea and the University of the South Pacific redesigned and decolonized their curriculum. item.title: Access Road to Water PNG washed out by heavy rain in Popondetta
item.description:
Heavy rainfall on New Year’s Eve has left the access road to the Water PNG facility in Popondetta severely damaged, creating significant hazards for motorists and pedestrians.

The damage was reportedly exacerbated by a blocked stormwater drain. According to local resident Mathew Malpaim, a discarded tyre was dumped into the drainage system, obstructing the natural flow of water.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

item.title: Bradley Wak calls for unity in Dei District with major peace offering
item.description:
Two tribes in the Dei District of Western Highlands Province have participated in a major reconciliation ceremony to restore solidarity and peace ahead of the 2026 calendar year.

The event, hosted by intending candidate for the Dei Open by-election, Baffinu Bradley Wak, marked a formal reunion between the Prandak and Kinsibi Rangikrambo tribes. The ceremony was organized to encourage both groups to set aside past differences and live as neighbors in harmony.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Bradley Wak calls for unity in Dei District with major peace offering appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: ICCC confirms fuel price to increase commencing on January 8
item.description:
The Independent Consumer and Competition Commission (ICCC) has announced the increase in wholesale, retail, and drum-filling prices for petrol, diesel, and kerosene to be effective starting January 8, 2026.

The acting chief executive officer, Brian Ivosa, said the annual adjustments were in accordance with the determinations of the 2024 Petroleum Industry pricing review, applying in the five-year (2024-2029) regulatory period.

item.title: Ela Murray International School brings holiday cheer to children at Port Moresby General Hospital
item.description:
The Ela Murray International School has extended the spirit of giving this festive season, delivering joy and comfort to young patients at Port Moresby General Hospital (PMGH).

As part of its Gift-a-Friend, Christmas and New Year Charity Drive, the school donated 250 gift bags filled with essential items and festive treats. The gifts, lovingly prepared by students and parents, were distributed across all five paediatric wards, ensuring children spending the holidays in hospital could share in the celebrations with their families.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Ela Murray International School brings holiday cheer to children at Port Moresby General Hospital appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: Don re-signs Edene on a new two-year contract
item.description:
The Dons have handed their 2026 campaign a massive boost with the confirmation that star winger Edene Gebbie has committed his future to the club. The reigning Player of the Year has officially signed a new two-year contract extension, keeping him at the heart of the squad’s ambitious push for the play-offs.

The 30-year-old Papua New Guinea international proved to be a revelation last season, finishing the year with a remarkable strike rate of 25 tries in just 22 appearances. His decision to extend his stay is a significant statement of intent for the club as they look to build on the momentum of the previous season.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Don re-signs Edene on a new two-year contract appeared first on Post Courier.
item.source:markdown:
![](https://www.postcourier.com.pg/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/The-reigning-Player-of-the-Year-has-officially-signed-a-new-two-year-contract-extension-1.jpg?w=800)
The Dons have handed their 2026 campaign a massive boost with the confirmation that star winger Edene Gebbie has committed his future to the club. The reigning Player of the Year has officially signed a new two-year contract extension, keeping him at the heart of the squad’s ambitious push for the play-offs.
The 30-year-old Papua New Guinea international proved to be a revelation last season, finishing the year with a remarkable strike rate of 25 tries in just 22 appearances. His decision to extend his stay is a significant statement of intent for the club as they look to build on the momentum of the previous season.

item.title: Ok Tedi strengthens community safety with support to Water Police
item.description:
OK Tedi Mining Limited (OTML) has donated four 200-litre drums of zoom to the Royal Papua New Guinea Constabulary (RPNGC) Water Police Directorate in Port Moresby.

The donation reaffirmed OTML’s commitment to community safety and law and order. The fuel support will enable the Water Police team to increase maritime patrols and maintain law and order across Fairfax Harbour, safeguarding it, the surrounding areas and the Motukea logistics corridor.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Ok Tedi strengthens community safety with support to Water Police appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: North Fly MP raises concerns over Ok Tedi mine’s environmental legacy
item.description:
Member for North Fly James Donald MP, has voiced urgent concerns regarding the ongoing environmental issues and the lack of proper consultation with local landowners concerning the future of Ok Tedi mine’s operations.

In a statement earlier this week, Mr. Donald highlighted that Ok Tedi Mining Limited (OTML) has failed to address persistent environmental degradation and has not secured the free and informed consent of the affected communities.

item.description: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department is seeking to enlist about 400 lawyers to review roughly 5.2 million pages of Epstein files documents, an effort that is drawing in prosecutors who work on national security and criminal cases, and in U.S. attorneys’ offices in New York and Florida, according to people familiar with the matter.

item.description: Christopher Brian Herbold, 41, of Kailua-Kona died Oct. 9 in Kailua-Kona. He was born in Seguin, Texas. Services at a later date. Survived by partner, Angela Taft; children, Derick Herbold, Kaison Herbold, Capri Herbold, Marley Herbold and Charlee Herbold; mother, Tami (William Newberg) Herbold; father, Alfredo (Brenda) Sanchez Jr.; sisters, Kristen (Clint) Jahns and Ceira Sanchez; brother, AD Sanchez; grandparents, Margaret Herbold and Ruben Sanchez; a niece a nephew, aunts, uncles and cousins. Arrangements by Dodo Mortuary.

item.title: Pavaia’i Elementary artwork displayed at the White House National Christmas Tree Exhibit
item.description:
By 
Samoa News staff
reporters@samoanews.com

Pago Pago, AMERICAN SAMOA — December 19, 2025) Pavaia’i Elementary School has received national recognition through the America Celebrates display, as artwork created by students from Ms. Loimata Siona’s 4th grade class were selected for exhibition at the White House. The program features handcrafted ornaments representing every U.S. state, territory, and the District of Columbia, all showcased around the iconic National Christmas Tree.

The ornaments submitted by Ms. Siona’s elementary class were designed during the previous school year, reflecting the culture, pride, and unique identity of American Samoa.

Each year, the America Celebrates program provides students across the nation with an opportunity to represent their home state or territory through original artwork that becomes part of a holiday tradition in the nation’s capital.

 The National Christmas Tree, along with the accompanying state and territory ornaments, will remain on display at the White House through January 1, 2026.

Visitors from around the world will have the opportunity to admire the creativity, talent, and cultural expression of young artists from across the United States and its territories. 

Visit the nationaltree.org/ornaments/american-samoa/ to view the complete collection of the American Samoa state ornaments.

 

Section: 
Local News
Tags: 
White House National Christmas Tree Exhibit
item.source:markdown:
[![American Samoa ornaments at White House](https://www.samoanews.com/sites/default/files/styles/slideshow/public/field/image/as_ornaments_at_white_hse.jpg?itok=ZuEtdBqA)](https://www.samoanews.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_normal_image/public/field/image/as_ornaments_at_white_hse.jpg?itok=jgzamaVW)

Samoa News staff

The program features handcrafted ornaments representing every U.S. state, territory, and the District of Columbia, all showcased around the iconic National Christmas Tree.
The ornaments submitted by Ms. Siona’s elementary class were designed during the previous school year, reflecting the culture, pride, and unique identity of American Samoa.
Each year, the America Celebrates program provides students across the nation with an opportunity to represent their home state or territory through original artwork that becomes part of a holiday tradition in the nation’s capital.
The National Christmas Tree, along with the accompanying state and territory ornaments, will remain on display at the White House through January 1, 2026.

item.title: Police halt dangerous tire fire near power pole at Tete Bus Stop
item.description:
Police intervention prevented a potentially hazardous situation today near the Tete bus stop, betel nut sales gate, where two young men were forced to extinguish a tire fire lit dangerously close to a power pole.

​Assistant Commissioner of Police (ACP) Ben Turi condemned the act, noting that the proximity to electrical infrastructure significantly increased the risk to public safety and essential services.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

item.title: CAPITAL WELCOMES NEW YEAR IN DARKNESS
item.description:
Despite an unexpected power outage, celebrations across the city have continued with energy and resilience as residents refuse to let the blackout dampen their New Year’s spirit.

The outage, believed to have occurred at approximately 10:40pm, left several parts of the city without electricity just moments before the final countdown to the end of 2025.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

item.title: PC Online Tidbits
item.description:
Seems PNG still will be walking into 2026 with more power blackouts, and water cuts. To add more value to our richness on this front,  now we also look largely blacked out on the satellite internet provider, Starlink’s, availability Map when we checked. There we are, the biggest blackest dot shaded in the region. All our teeny tiny neighbours in the Pacific shining bright like diamonds are part of more than 150 countries moving forward while we take a different path we anticipate with this.

The post PC Online Tidbits appeared first on Post Courier.
item.source:markdown:
![](https://www.postcourier.com.pg/wp-content/uploads/2024/04/TIDBITS-FEATURED-PIC.png?w=800)

All our teeny tiny neighbours in the Pacific shining bright like diamonds are part of more than 150 countries moving forward while we take a different path we anticipate with this.

item.description: Russell Y. Hatada, 74, of Hilo, died Dec. 9 at home. Born in Hilo, he was a retired baker for the former Robert’s Bakery. Private services held. Online condolences: www.homelanimemorialpark.com. Survived by daughter, Erin (Keith) Nacis of Hilo; sister, Cheryl Ferreira; sister-in-law, Lynn Hatada; two grandchildren; aunts, uncles, nieces and nephews. Arrangements by Homelani Memorial Park.

item.title: Looking forward together to all the possibilities for a wonderful new year
item.description:
By 
Samoa News staff
reporters@samoanews.com

Pago Pago, AMERICAN SAMOA — In this beautiful photo, Congresswoman Uifa’atali Aumua Amata remembered our loved ones far away due to military service, collegiate studies, or careers in the states.

“May God especially bless and each of them and these families, with ‘many happy returns’ to our island home. This Christmas, we keep our Toa o Samoa especially in our prayers – thank you to each one for your service and sacrifice! Just this week, Congress sent next year’s 3.8 percent pay raise for our military to the President to be signed into law, as part of a busy December.

“We look forward together to all the possibilities for a wonderful new year. May each of us celebrate this special season with joyful and charitable hearts.”

 

 

Section: 
Local News
Tags: 
Congresswoman Uifa’atali Aumua Amata

“We look forward together to all the possibilities for a wonderful new year. May each of us celebrate this special season with joyful and charitable hearts.”

item.title: Ring in the New Year with promises of renewal, reflection and hope
item.description:
By 
Samoa News staff
reporters@samoanews.com

 

Pago Pago, AMERICAN SAMOA — In observance of the New Year holiday, Governor Pulaali’i Nikolau Pula has announced that the government will officially take two days off — Thursday, January 1, 2026 and Friday, January 2nd. However, Wednesday, while not a holiday, will be a half day, with an early release from work at 12p.m.

As per usual on a government holiday all government offices will be closed, and normal operations will be suspended. Employees of the American Samoa Government who are not required to perform essential services shall be excused from duty. Those employees whose duties are essential and are required to work on these holidays shall receive holiday compensation in accordance with applicable laws and regulations.

“Government operations shall resume under normal business hours on Monday, January 5th 2026.

“The New Year marks a time of renewal, reflection, and hope as we look ahead to new opportunities and responsibilities. It is also a moment to give thanks for God’s guidance and blessings throughout the past year. Employees are encouraged to spend this time with family and loved ones, reflect on the yer past, and prepare for the year ahead with renewed purpose, unity, and commitment in serving our community.”

Governor Puaali’i extends his sincere appreciation for their continued service and dedication to the people of the Territory. “May the New Year bring you good health, success, and prosperity.

Samoa News should note that the governor is currently off island, with no return date currently announced.

The US Post Office Service will be closed New Year’s Day, returning on Friday, Jan. 2nd, as per normal federal holiday.

The Territorial Bank of American Samoa (TBAS) will close early at 12 pm, on Wednesday, December 31, 2025; on Thursday, Jan 1, 2026 it will be closed; and, it will be open on Friday, Jan. 2nd for full service.

Don’t forget American Samoa is the last “inhabited” country to ring in the New Year — if you want to see the last sunset of 2025 in the Territory, take a ride out to Poloa. On the other hand, if you want to experience the first New Year celebration in the world, you need to fly to Samoa, with the holidays experiencing some of the the busiest flight times for the inter-island airlines.

For StarKist Samoa its cannery shutdown continues for the Christmas and New Year holidays. The shutdown allows for major maintenance work and prepares the cannery for the new year, with the company slated to begin production of pet food in 2026.

With more than 80% of the cannery workforce of more than 2,000 being from Samoa, they have headed home for the holidays. The cannery did arrange for a charter of the Lady Samoa ferry to take its employees to Samoa during Christmas week. It’s unknown if a return-trip ferry has been chartered.

The company’s first day of production for 2026 is scheduled for Monday, Jan. 5th.

Usually New Year in the Territory highlights its NY Eve’s church services before the bars begin to fill to ring in the brand new year.

On New Year Day, look for family or company barbecues at the public beaches and parks. Most grocery stores will be open, with specialty stores and companies usually closing on that day, with all returning to full service on Friday.

According to the National Weather Service- Pago Pago, the weather forecast for New Year’s Day is partly cloudy, isolated showers, highs in the upper 80s, and variable winds up to 10 mph. It looks like mostly a sunny day.

From Thursday night through to Friday, its still partly cloudy however, scattered showers are forecast.

Friday night through Sunday, the weather is mostly cloudy with numerous showers — definitely expect rain throughout the weekend.

For the public’s safety, the police are continuing their Enforcement initiative that began about 2 weeks ago, marking the beginning of a focused effort to enhance road safety during the busy festive season. 

Commissioner of Public Safety Taaga Saite Moliga announced the Enforcement initiative noting the deployment of strategically placed roadblocks throughout the community to identify and evaluate drivers suspected of being under the influence of alcohol or drugs. He noted these roadblocks would be strategically placed in response to real-time traffic patterns, focusing on high-traffic areas during peak travel periods to maximize visibility and effectiveness.

The DPS is maintaining its Holiday Enforcement program, through Saturday, January 3, 2026. 

Samoa News will have an issue tomorrow, December 31st, New Year’s eve day and will be off on Thursday, Jan 1st and Friday, Jan. 2nd, returning on Monday, Jan 5th, 2026.

Happy New Year — American Samoa. Be safe, and with God’s grace may we ring in the New Year remembering to be kind to one another.

Section: 
Local News
Tags: 
NEW YEAR 2026
item.source:markdown:
[![poloa sunset](https://www.samoanews.com/sites/default/files/styles/slideshow/public/field/image/poloa_sunset_3270web_0.jpg?itok=_oKthwAl)](https://www.samoanews.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_normal_image/public/field/image/poloa_sunset_3270web_0.jpg?itok=Rexg5oDc)

item.title: Madang Police neutralise Gagasi Lagoon settlement after festive season crimes
item.description:

The operation took place on Friday, December 27, 2025, at about 5pm. It was conducted under the Christmas and New Year police operations, known as "SAIN ABE 3".

item.title: Australian tourist says PNG visit was memorable but ended early
item.description:
An Australian tourist says her visit to Papua New Guinea was memorable but ended earlier than planned after the cruise vessel Coral Adventurer ran aground off the Finschhafen coast.

“We visited some remote islands in Papua New Guinea and found everyone extremely friendly and welcoming,” the tourist said. “We loved visiting the villages, meeting the children, and seeing the schools. The snorkelling was amazing, with beautiful reefs and fish. Unfortunately, our adventure ended due to the vessel incident.”

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Australian tourist says PNG visit was memorable but ended early appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: Falcons blow 3-TD lead, edge Rams on late field goal
item.description: After jumping out to a 21-0 halftime lead, the Atlanta Falcons held on to upset the Los Angeles Rams 27-24. The Falcons won their third straight game and improved to 7-9, while the Rams dropped their second straight and fell to 11-5.

item.title: US strikes drug boat loading facility in Venezuela, Trump says

item.title: Obituaries for December 30
item.description: Perfectua Castanero Babiera, 88, of Hilo died Dec. 1 at Life Care Center of Hilo. Born in the Philippines, she was a sorter for Mauna Loa Macadamia Nut Co. and member of the St. Joseph Catholic Church. Visitation 4-6 p.m. Thursday, Jan. 8, at Dodo Mortuary Chapel. Wake service at 6 p.m. Visitation again 8-9:30 a.m. Friday, Jan. 9, at St. Joseph Catholic Church. Mass at 9;30 a.m. Burial to follow at Homelani Memorial Park, Ilima Section. Survived by niece/hanai daughter, Joceyln (Albert Lagronio) Lazaga of Hilo; two grandchildren. nieces and nephews. Arrangements by Dodo Mortuary.

Survived by niece/hanai daughter, Joceyln (Albert Lagronio) Lazaga of Hilo; two grandchildren. nieces and nephews. Arrangements by Dodo Mortuary.

item.title: New Year’s Eve concerts at Kennedy Center are canceled
item.description: A veteran jazz ensemble and a New York dance company have canceled events at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, intensifying the fallout at one of the nation’s preeminent arts centers after it was renamed to include President Donald Trump.

item.title: US economy to ride tax cut tailwind but faces risks
item.description: A ​see-saw year for the U.S. economy in ‌2025 looks set to give way to a stronger 2026 thanks to tailwinds from President Donald Trump’s ‌tax cuts, less uncertainty around tariffs, the ongoing artificial intelligence boom and a late-year run of interest-rate reductions from the Federal Reserve.
item.source:markdown: A ​see-saw year for the U.S. economy in ‌2025 looks set to give way to a stronger 2026 thanks to tailwinds from President Donald Trump’s ‌tax cuts, less uncertainty around tariffs, the ongoing artificial intelligence boom and a late-year run of interest-rate reductions from the Federal Reserve.

item.title: Democrats aim to spotlight Republican efforts to rewrite the Jan. 6 Capitol riot
item.description: WASHINGTON — When they return to Washington next week, House Democrats plan to mark the fifth anniversary of the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol with an informal hearing that will highlight Republicans’ efforts to rewrite the history of a riot by a pro-Trump mob.
item.source:markdown: WASHINGTON — When they return to Washington next week, House Democrats plan to mark the fifth anniversary of the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol with an informal hearing that will highlight Republicans’ efforts to rewrite the history of a riot by a pro-Trump mob.

item.title: China stages record drills designed to encircle Taiwan
item.description: BEIJING/TAIPEI — China launched its most extensive war games around Taiwan on Monday to showcase Beijing’s ability to cut off the ‌island from outside support in a conflict, as President Donald Trump downplayed the threat behind the drills.

item.title: Judge grants release of redacted transcript of Charlie Kirk case hearing
item.description: A Utah judge overseeing the trial of the accused killer of conservative activist Charlie Kirk on Monday ordered the release of most ‍of the transcript and audio of a closed-door hearing on safety and security measures for the proceedings, but said media outlets who had asked for the records did not need special status to cover ​the proceedings. Judge Tony Graf made his two rulings ​on media requests during a video hearing that suspect Tyler Robinson attended by audio link. Robinson spoke only once, replying “yes, your honor,” when asked by Graf whether he was present.
item.source:markdown: A Utah judge overseeing the trial of the accused killer of conservative activist Charlie Kirk on Monday ordered the release of most ‍of the transcript and audio of a closed-door hearing on safety and security measures for the proceedings, but said media outlets who had asked for the records did not need special status to cover ​the proceedings. Judge Tony Graf made his two rulings ​on media requests during a video hearing that suspect Tyler Robinson attended by audio link. Robinson spoke only once, replying “yes, your honor,” when asked by Graf whether he was present.

item.title: US could block asylum on public health grounds under Trump regulation
item.description: WASHINGTON — The U.S. could ​deny migrants access to ‌asylum on the grounds they present ‌a public health risk under a newly finalized regulation drafted during the COVID-19 pandemic in President Donald Trump’s first term.
item.source:markdown: WASHINGTON — The U.S. could ​deny migrants access to ‌asylum on the grounds they present ‌a public health risk under a newly finalized regulation drafted during the COVID-19 pandemic in President Donald Trump’s first term.

item.title: Washington pipe bomb suspect has confessed, prosecutors say
item.description: WASHINGTON — The man ‌accused of planting pipe bombs in Washington the night before the January 6, 2021, U.S. Capitol attack confessed to the FBI and told investigators he thought the 2020 election had been “tampered with,” according to ‍a court filing from federal prosecutors. Brian Cole, 30, of Virginia admitted to planting the devices, neither of which exploded, outside the headquarters of the Democratic and Republican national committees following his arrest ​earlier this month, according to the filing, which ​was made public on Sunday.
item.source:markdown: WASHINGTON — The man ‌accused of planting pipe bombs in Washington the night before the January 6, 2021, U.S. Capitol attack confessed to the FBI and told investigators he thought the 2020 election had been “tampered with,” according to ‍a court filing from federal prosecutors. Brian Cole, 30, of Virginia admitted to planting the devices, neither of which exploded, outside the headquarters of the Democratic and Republican national committees following his arrest ​earlier this month, according to the filing, which ​was made public on Sunday.

item.title: Let’s Talk Food: New Year’s is this Thursday
item.description: This Thursday is New Year’s Day, filled with ritual and tradition for most of Japanese ancestry. The house has to be cleaned of all the old dust from the old year and all debts must be paid off before the year’s end — which is impossible if you have a car loan or a mortgage.
item.source:markdown: This Thursday is New Year’s Day, filled with ritual and tradition for most of Japanese ancestry. The house has to be cleaned of all the old dust from the old year and all debts must be paid off before the year’s end — which is impossible if you have a car loan or a mortgage.

item.title: Five weeknight dishes: Fancy mains without the time commitment
item.description: It’s a funny time of year to be writing to you about fast and simple cooking. Is this not the moment for luxury, pageantry and scale, for projects like tamales or lumpia that require a gathering of home cooks and many hands; or Caribbean black cake, with its jeweled dried and candied fruit soaked for up to a year; or a perfect prime rib roast, a grand and true statement piece?
item.source:markdown: It’s a funny time of year to be writing to you about fast and simple cooking. item.title: Lae to close 2025 with high-energy New Year’s party at Jokema’s Inn
item.description:
Lae will usher out 2025 in emphatic style this Wednesday night with a major New Year celebration at Jokema’s Inn, as Morobe’s vibrant music, fashion and creative scene takes centre stage from 7 pm till late.

Billed as the Jokema’s Inn New Year Party, the event brings together a strong lineup of homegrown performers headlined by Siassi Heritage, Trevor Serum, Jnr Kro and Elbig Raingz, artists known for blending contemporary sounds with strong cultural identity and local storytelling.

item.title: Ramu NiCo staff celebrated Xmas as one big Ramu NiCo family
item.description:
The Ramu NiCo staff at the Madang head office celebrated Christmas 2025 with excitement and holiday cheer as they gathered on Wednesday, December 24, for their annual celebration. It is a long-standing Ramu NiCo tradition to celebrate the season every year as one united family.

Organised by the company management and attended by all employees, the event was a testament to the company's spirit. The Corporate Team worked tirelessly to decorate the office reception area; as staff entered the beautifully adorned hall, they were immediately greeted by the festive atmosphere. The celebration featured Christmas carols playing in the background, a wide array of food and drinks, and a centrepiece Christmas cake.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Ramu NiCo staff celebrated Xmas as one big Ramu NiCo family appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: Vetiver grass used to protect farms and infrastructure in Markham
item.description:
Vetiver grass is being used by farmers in Markham to reduce flooding, landslides, and soil erosion.

John Gaif, President of the Markham Smart Farmers Association, said vetiver is known as the “Miracle Grass” because of its deep root system. He said the roots can grow up to 15 metres into the soil.

item.title: PNG Power rebuild begins in Lae
item.description:
PNG Power Limited has begun a major rebuild of Lae’s electricity network, signalling a decisive push to end years of neglect that have left the city crippled by frequent power outages.

Speaking on Wednesday, December 17 to the Lae business community, PNG Power Chief Executive Officer Paul Bayly said the overhaul is part of a nationwide effort to restore reliable electricity by fixing generation, transmission and distribution systems that have failed to keep pace with demand.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

item.title: Lae Mayor orders full investigation into Lipo Factory
item.description:
LAE City Lord Mayor Jacob Maragau has ordered a full probe into the operations of the Lipo factory at Kamkumung.

item.description: Brigitte Bardot, the pouty, tousle-haired French actress who redefined mid-20th-century movie sex symbolism in films beginning with “And God Created Woman,” then gave up acting at 39 to devote her life to the welfare of animals, died Sunday at her home in southern France. She was 91.

item.title: Dismissed Police Officer in police uniform extorting gets arrested
item.description:
An ex-police officer identified as George Fuki from a mix parentage of East Sepik and New Ireland who was dismissed in 2024 was arrested this morning while wearing a police uniform and trying to extort money from a man at the airport.

National Capital District Metropolitan Superintendent Warrick Simatab confirmed that the suspect, who is now detained at Six Mile police station, was apprehended by police units who were searching for him.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Dismissed Police Officer in police uniform extorting gets arrested appeared first on Post Courier.
item.source:markdown:
![](https://www.postcourier.com.pg/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/DFGEAFDSVCX.jpg?w=888)
An ex-police officer identified as George Fuki from a mix parentage of East Sepik and New Ireland who was dismissed in 2024 was arrested this morning while wearing a police uniform and trying to extort money from a man at the airport.
National Capital District Metropolitan Superintendent Warrick Simatab confirmed that the suspect, who is now detained at Six Mile police station, was apprehended by police units who were searching for him.

item.title: Where the CHamoru culture was born
item.description: Litekyan, an archeological site at the northern point of Guam, is the birthplace of pre-Spanish CHamoru civilization before it later became a front of the natives’ resistance against the European colonizers. These days, the ancient CHamoru village site embodies the conflict between the growing military presence on Guam and the effort to preserve the island’s culture.
item.source:markdown: Litekyan, an archeological site at the northern point of Guam, is the birthplace of pre-Spanish CHamoru civilization before it later became a front of the natives’ resistance against the European colonizers. item.title: Australian-registered vessel runs aground off Finschhafen coast
item.description:
An Australian-registered vessel, the MV Coral Adventurer, remains stranded after running aground on a coral reef off the coast of Finschhafen early Saturday morning.

The incident occurred at approximately 5:25 AM. Local reports indicate that the vessel’s left-hand side became firmly trapped on the reef, preventing the ship from moving under its own power.

item.title: Port Moresby water supply set to recover as raw water quality stabilises
item.description:
Water supply across the National Capital District is expected to return to normal levels throughout Monday following a successful stabilisation of raw water quality at the main intake.

Water PNG confirmed late Sunday night that turbidity levels (NTU)—which had previously hindered the treatment process—have finally returned to acceptable limits. The improvement in water clarity has allowed technical teams to begin the critical process of restarting the flow to the city's primary treatment facilities.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Port Moresby water supply set to recover as raw water quality stabilises appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: Fire a big threat in PNG towns
item.description:
More than 14 small and medium size businesses in Mendi, Southern Highlands are still struggling to accept their loses after two separate fires gutted the buildings they were operating in last week.

The causes of the fires are not known at this stage, however the businesses have lost millions of kina to the fires which have left a population devastated with the locals openly weeping over their town.

item.title: PM to create communal reconciliation space in Tari
item.description:
To strengthen traditional conflict resolution, among his people in Tari, Prime Minister James Marape has announced plans to establish a communal reconciliation space in the Tari Pori District of Hela Province.

 “I will buy land the size of a soccer field and convert it into a communal place where we can come together to resolve our problems. Resolve issues among yourselves and do not always wait for police to come,” he said.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

item.title: How did DOGE disrupt so much while saving so little?
item.description: WASHINGTON — Elon Musk’s Department of Government Efficiency said it made more than 29,000 cuts to the federal government — slashing billion-dollar contracts, canceling thousands of grants and pushing out civil servants.
item.source:markdown: WASHINGTON — Elon Musk’s Department of Government Efficiency said it made more than 29,000 cuts to the federal government — slashing billion-dollar contracts, canceling thousands of grants and pushing out civil servants.

item.title: Russia pummels Kyiv before Trump-Zelenskyy meeting
item.description: KYIV, Ukraine — Russia pounded the Ukrainian capital with waves of missiles and attack drones Saturday, an hourslong assault that came the day before President Volodymyr Zelenskyy of Ukraine’s scheduled meeting in Florida with President Donald Trump to discuss a plan to end the war.
item.source:markdown: KYIV, Ukraine — Russia pounded the Ukrainian capital with waves of missiles and attack drones Saturday, an hourslong assault that came the day before President Volodymyr Zelenskyy of Ukraine’s scheduled meeting in Florida with President Donald Trump to discuss a plan to end the war.

item.title: How much more can the US travel industry take?
item.description: The United States routinely tops the list of foreign travelers’ dream destinations. They can’t seem to get enough of Manhattan’s skyscrapers, the mountains of Vermont, the hedonistic nightlife of Las Vegas, Hawaii’s pristine beaches and the dreamscapes of Disney parks.

item.title: Thailand and Cambodia reach ceasefire in brutal border war
item.description: The defense ministers of Thailand and Cambodia said Saturday that they had agreed to a 72-hour ceasefire, possibly paving the way for an end to a brutal 20-day border war that killed dozens of people and displaced hundreds of thousands more.
item.source:markdown: The defense ministers of Thailand and Cambodia said Saturday that they had agreed to a 72-hour ceasefire, possibly paving the way for an end to a brutal 20-day border war that killed dozens of people and displaced hundreds of thousands more.

item.title: Myanmar polls open amid civil war, junta-backed party tipped to win
item.description: (Reuters) — Overshadowed by civil war ‌and doubts about the credibility of the polls, voters in Myanmar were casting their ballots ‌in a general election starting on Sunday, the first since a military coup toppled the last civilian government in 2021.

item.title: Obituaries for December 28
item.description: Brian E. Antida, 65, of Hilo died Nov. 17 at home. Born in Hilo, he was an investigator for the Office of the Prosecuting Attorney, and previously with the Department of Liquor Control, a Hawaii County Police Department officer, Hilo Drivers Licensing Department and the former Hukilau Hotel. Visitation 9:30-11 a.m. Saturday (Jan. 3) at Dodo Mortuary Chapel. Memorial prayer service at 11. Casual attire. Survived by wife, Pam Antida of Hilo; daughter, Blake Ann (Jensen) Sato of Hilo; brothers, Warren (Meagan) Antida of San Jose, Calif., John (Chris Gomera-Nicolas) Camero of Mountain View; a granddaughter, aunts, uncles, cousins, nieces and nephews. Arrangements by Dodo Mortuary.
item.source:markdown: Brian E. Antida, 65, of Hilo died Nov. 17 at home. item.title: Winter weather in Northeast leads to thousands of flight delays, cancellations
item.description: NEW YORK (Reuters) — A mix of snow and ice bore down on the U.S. Northeast early on Saturday, disrupting post-holiday weekend airline traffic and prompting officials in New York and New Jersey to issue ‍weather emergency declarations even as the storm ebbed by mid-morning.
item.source:markdown: NEW YORK (Reuters) — A mix of snow and ice bore down on the U.S. Northeast early on Saturday, disrupting post-holiday weekend airline traffic and prompting officials in New York and New Jersey to issue ‍weather emergency declarations even as the storm ebbed by mid-morning.

item.title: Steves: Christmas in France
item.description: As it is in so many places, Christmas in France is all about family, friends, and food. While it’s generally a low-key affair marked by gatherings of relatives and treats for children, it also has the culinary high point of the year: Le Réveillon de Noël (Christmas Eve dinner).
item.source:markdown: As it is in so many places, Christmas in France is all about family, friends, and food. item.title: Natives crowned kings of Rhinos 10s Sydney Wesley Cup
item.description:
The Gerehu Natives have been crowned the champions of the Rhinos 10s Sydney Wesley Cup after a gruelling two-day tournament that concluded today, Sunday, December 28th, at the home of rugby union in Port Moresby.

The Natives secured the title in a dramatic extra-time playoff, defeating the New Town Chiefs with a 3-0 penalty conversion. To reach the grand final, the Natives had earlier outplayed the Bomana Young Guns with a 17-5 victory.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

item.title: NCD Governor’s Netball Cup highlights push for gender equality
item.description:
The launch of the NCD Governor’s Netball Cup today sends a strong message about gender equality in sport, providing women and girls with a competitive platform alongside male-dominated competitions such as rugby league and soccer.

Governor Powes Parkop said the Cup is part of a broader effort to address historical imbalances in opportunities, funding, and visibility between men’s and women’s sports.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The launch of the NCD Governor’s Netball Cup today sends a strong message about gender equality in sport, providing women and girls with a competitive platform alongside male-dominated competitions such as rugby league and soccer.
Governor Powes Parkop said the Cup is part of a broader effort to address historical imbalances in opportunities, funding, and visibility between men’s and women’s sports.

item.title: NCD Governor’s Netball Cup brings communities together
item.description:
The inaugural Governor’s Netball Cup launched today at Rita Flynn Court, bringing together teams and supporters from across Port Moresby in a celebration of community, sport, and festive cheer.

Governor Powes Parkop said the event provides an opportunity to unite communities from different suburbs, cultural backgrounds, and tribes. “Sport is a powerful tool for building bridges and fostering understanding between people. The Governor’s Cup has always aimed to promote unity, and the Netball Cup takes that mission forward,” he said.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post NCD Governor’s Netball Cup brings communities together appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: NCD’s festive traffic crisis: 42 accidents in 10 days
item.description:

Following a 10-day traffic enforcement crackdown starting from Dec 18 to 28, 2025, the Metropolitan Superintendent confirmed that police are shifting into a high-intensity phase to ensure the city moves safely into 2026.

item.title: Hiri East youths establish neighborhood watch to ensure festive season safety
item.description:
Youths from Ward 4 of the Hiri East Koiari Local Level Government (LLG) area in Central Province have committed to forming a neighbourhood watch team to help maintain peace and security in their community during the festive season.

The initiative involves a dedicated group of youth volunteers maintaining an almost 24-hour presence along roadsides and within the village, operating daily from 6pm to 5am. The increased vigilance has enabled the group to closely monitor the movement of people in the area, particularly intoxicated individuals, helping to deter disturbances and promote harmony within the community.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Hiri East youths establish neighborhood watch to ensure festive season safety appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: Judge grants injunction blocking US from detaining British anti-disinformation activist
item.description: WASHINGTON — A U.S. judge on Thursday temporarily blocked the Trump administration from detaining British anti-disinformation campaigner Imran Ahmed, after the U.S. permanent resident sued officials over an entry ban for his role in what Washington argues is online censorship. Washington imposed visa bans on Tuesday on Ahmed and four Europeans, including French ‍former EU commissioner Thierry Breton. It accuses them of working to censor freedom of speech or unfairly target U.S. tech giants with burdensome regulation. Ahmed lives in Washington and is believed to be the only of the five currently in the country. The move sparked an outcry from European governments ​who argue regulations and the work of monitoring groups made the internet safer by ​highlighting false information and compelling tech giants to do more to tackle illegal content, including hate speech and child sexual abuse material.
item.source:markdown: WASHINGTON — A U.S. judge on Thursday temporarily blocked the Trump administration from detaining British anti-disinformation campaigner Imran Ahmed, after the U.S. permanent resident sued officials over an entry ban for his role in what Washington argues is online censorship. It accuses them of working to censor freedom of speech or unfairly target U.S. tech giants with burdensome regulation. Ahmed lives in Washington and is believed to be the only of the five currently in the country. The move sparked an outcry from European governments ​who argue regulations and the work of monitoring groups made the internet safer by ​highlighting false information and compelling tech giants to do more to tackle illegal content, including hate speech and child sexual abuse material.

item.title: Water PNG battles infrastructure decay: recovery underway in Lae
item.description:
Water PNG is currently navigating a series of critical infrastructure challenges in Lae, as aging equipment and decades of under-investment take a toll on the city’s water supply.

Water PNG CEO James Young reported that the situation reached a crisis point recently when a series of mechanical and electrical failures left only three of the city’s seven bore pumps operational.

item.title: Water PNG CEO admits Port Moresby lacks adequate water storage to survive shutdowns
item.description:
The CEO of Water PNG, James Young, has admitted that the nation’s capital lacks the necessary water storage capacity to withstand even "relatively short" maintenance activities without widespread outages.

The charge comes as residents face a grim end to the festive season. A planned shutdown by PNG Power at Rouna 2, scheduled from 10pm tonight December 27, 2025 through Sunday, Dec 28, is expected to cripple the city's water supply.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

item.title: Court sends strong warning on mining land claims as Wafi-Golpu case heads to trial
item.description:
A Lae magistrate has sent a clear warning to land groups linked to major resource projects, committing two Morobe men to stand trial over alleged fraudulent land registration tied to the Wafi-Golpu gold and copper project.

Steven Kozi Judah, 45, and Jack Raban, 38, both from Babuaf village in Huon Gulf, were committed to the National Court last Wednesday after the court found there was enough evidence for them to answer serious fraud-related charges.

item.title: Obituaries for December 26
item.description: Bernard Bertin Noguès, 86, of Waimea died Dec. 9 at Queen’s North Hawaii Community Hospital. Born in Houilles, France, he was a retired teacher and administrator for Hawaii Preparatory Academy and avid golfer, tennis player and fisherman. Visitation 9:30-10:30 a.m. Saturday, Jan. 3, at Annunciation Catholic Church in Waimea. Remembrances and eulogy at 10:30. Mass at 11 a.m. Private burial to follow. Gathering at his home at 2 p.m. Aloha attire. Survived by wife, Mary-Alice Noguès of Waimea; children, Mireille (Manjit Singh) Urbani of Indianapolis, Marguerite (Alan) Heap of Waimea André Noguès of Ashland, Ore., Marina (Bradford Cole) Noguès of Honolulu and Jean Noguès of Waimea; sister, Marina Kaiser of France; three grandchildren and two great-grandchildren; cousins, nieces and nephews. Arrangements by Dodo Mortuary.

item.title: Port Moresby faces 50% water reduction as Rouna 2 maintenance begins
item.description:
Residents of the National Capital District are being urged to store water ahead of a major planned shutdown of the Rouna 2 power station, which is expected to slash water production by half this weekend.

The maintenance work, scheduled by PNG Power, will commence at 10:00 PM on Saturday, December 27, and continue through Sunday, December 28, 2025.

item.title: Ramu Grid restoration underway after Christmas power failure
item.description:
Technical crews are working to restore full power to the Highlands region today after a major transmission fault left residents in the dark for much of the Christmas period.

PNG Power Limited (PPL) confirmed this morning that while the Ramu Grid is operating normally for most of Lae, Madang, and parts of the Highlands, a “permanent fault” on the main Transmission Line 507 has forced a split in generation.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

item.title: Marape hails ‘Monumental’ revenue success despite massive tax relief
item.description:
Prime Minister James Marape has lauded the country’s financial agencies for achieving record-breaking revenue collections in 2025, despite the government implementing the largest tax relief package in Papua New Guinea’s history.

During a year-end press conference, the Prime Minister revealed that the Internal Revenue Commission (IRC) has already collected 97% of its total 2025 forecast. These collections are K700 million higher than the same period last year.

item.title: FRASA students bring hope to remote Olsobip community
item.description:
More than 150 students, professionals and church parents from the Fly River Adventist Students Association (FRASA) are serving the Olsobip community in North Fly District, Western Province, through a two-week convention focused on faith, service and community development.

FRASA members have been actively involved in community service, including grass cutting around the Olsobip Health Centre, cleaning community roads, conducting health awareness and education programs, donating clothes, distributing inspirational literature, and sharing messages of hope and encouragement.

item.title: White House orders military to focus on ‘quarantine’ of Venezuela oil
item.description: WASHINGTON — ‌The White House has ordered U.S. military forces to focus almost exclusively on enforcing a “quarantine” of Venezuelan oil for at least the next two months, a U.S. official told Reuters, indicating Washington is currently more interested in using economic rather than military means to pressure Caracas. “While military options still exist, the ‍focus is to first use economic pressure by enforcing sanctions to reach the outcome the White House is looking (for),” the official said on Wednesday, speaking on condition of anonymity. While President Donald Trump has been publicly coy about his precise aims regarding Venezuela, he has privately pressured Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro to ​flee the nation, Reuters has reported. Trump said on Monday it would be ​smart for Maduro to leave power.
item.source:markdown: WASHINGTON — ‌The White House has ordered U.S. military forces to focus almost exclusively on enforcing a “quarantine” of Venezuelan oil for at least the next two months, a U.S. official told Reuters, indicating Washington is currently more interested in using economic rather than military means to pressure Caracas. “While military options still exist, the ‍focus is to first use economic pressure by enforcing sanctions to reach the outcome the White House is looking (for),” the official said on Wednesday, speaking on condition of anonymity. While President Donald Trump has been publicly coy about his precise aims regarding Venezuela, he has privately pressured Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro to ​flee the nation, Reuters has reported. Trump said on Monday it would be ​smart for Maduro to leave power.

In return, Palau will receive $7.5 million and other aid.

item.title: Weight-loss pill approval set to accelerate food industry product overhauls
item.description: NEW YORK — Packaged food makers and fast-food restaurants may ‌be forced to overhaul more of their products next year as newly approved, appetite-suppressing GLP-1 pills become available in January, analysts say. More Americans are expected to try the drugs as a pill rather than as a shot because the medication will be cheaper and many patients are hesitant to inject themselves. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration approved Novo Nordisk’s Wegovy GLP-1 pill on ‍Monday, sending shares of food companies down on Tuesday. Eli Lilly’s rival medication is expected to gain approval from regulators next year.
item.source:markdown: NEW YORK — Packaged food makers and fast-food restaurants may ‌be forced to overhaul more of their products next year as newly approved, appetite-suppressing GLP-1 pills become available in January, analysts say. item.title: MKA Chairman leads move to wipe out illicit homebrew in Hanuabada
item.description:
In a historic breakthrough for the Motu-Koitabu people, more than ten homebrew producers in Hanuabada have voluntarily surrendered their distillation equipment, marking a major step toward ending the village’s long-standing struggle with illicit alcohol.

The voluntary surrender followed a targeted operation spearheaded by the Chairman of the Motu-Koitabu Assembly (MKA), Russell S. Wavik, aimed at dismantling the rampant sale of "faiya-wara" and the illegal display of alcohol at the Hanuabada roadside market.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

item.title: What does Christmas mean to you?
item.description:
Christmas Day is a time of reflection and faith for many Papua New Guineans. While denominations observe it in different ways, some focusing on the day rather than the historical event that occurred that shaped PNG’s religious outlook, the meaning remains the same: the birth of Christ and hope for the world. We spoke to young and old at St Joseph's Catholic Parish Boroko to hear their thoughts: What does Christmas mean to you?

item.title: Karkar Island murder suspect surrenders to Police
item.description:
The main suspect in a killing on Karkar Island has surrendered to police in Madang. Owen Tergok, 24, from Gial village, gave himself up at Jomba Police Station on Wednesday.

Police say the crime happened on November 6, 2025. Two young men from Urugen village were returning home after selling copra. They were stopped and robbed.

item.title: Francis Mauigoa helps Hurricanes back to the ‘Cotton Bowl’ – Rumored to be 1st round NFL Draft Pick
item.description:
By 
Tony Gasu
Samoa News Correspondent

Pago Pago, AMERICAN SAMOA — Son of American Samoa – Francis Mauigoa from the village of Ili’ili, continues to wreak havoc on the football field with the University of Miami “Hurricanes” (No.10), who defeated the Texas A&M (No.7) in a historic 10 - 3 victory this past weekend. They are now scheduled to face the Ohio State ‘Buckeyes’ (No.2) in the Cotton Bowl that is set to kick off on New Year’s Eve, December 31, 2025.

Mauigoa was named Consensus All-American, by the NCAA last Friday. The 6’6, 335lbs anchors a 11-2 Miami Hurricanes team who have much improved from their 10-3 record from last season.

To be named a Consensus All-American, a student-athlete must receive First Team All-America honors from at least three of the five NCAA-recognized selectors: the Associated Press, American Football Coaches Association, Football Writers Association of America, The Sporting News and the Walter Camp Football Foundation.

According to the University of Florida’s recent media release, Mauigoa, received First Team honors from The Sporting News, the Associated Press and the Walter Camp Football Foundation. He anchored an offensive line that powered one of the ACC’s most productive rushing attacks, as Miami totaled 2,456 rushing yards while averaging 188.9 yards per game and 5.7 yards per carry. The Hurricanes also scored 30 rushing touchdowns and limited negative plays, allowing just 203 yards lost on the ground throughout the season.

Francis graduated earlier this month with his Bachelor of Science degree in Communication, earning his Bachelor’s in just three years. Most college students take four to five years to complete their degree, which makes this accomplishment even more impressive.

University of Miami graduate Francis Mauigoa, posing with his parent Fa’alialia and Telesia Mauigoa, during his graduation earlier this month, (December 11, 2025). Francis graduated with his Bachelor’s of Science in Communication, earning his Bachelor’s degree in three years – Most college students take four to five years to complete their degree, which makes this accomplishment even more impressive. [photo: courtesy]

Mauigoa who is rumored to be a first round draft pick in the 2026 NFL Draft, is the son of Telesia and Fa’alialia Mauigoa of Ili’ili. His older brother and former teammate, Francisco Mauigoa currently plays linebacker for the New York Jets Football Team.

KEIKI MISIPEKA — PERSONNEL DEPARTMENT, UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI

Adding to the significant changes within the University of Miami football program is another Son of Samoa, Keiki Misipeka. Misipeka works in recruiting and personnel and has been part of the program for nearly a year.

During his career, Misipeka has helped and assisted numerous student-athletes from American Samoa, guiding them to Division I and junior college football opportunities. He previously served as the General Manager of Football at the University of Hawaiʻi, taking over the role for the Rainbow Warriors in 2024 after spending two seasons as the running backs coach.

Prior to his time coaching in the Mountain West Conference, Misipeka served as an NFL International Scout for the International Player Pathway (IPP) Program, where he was responsible for scouting the Pacific region, including American Samoa, Samoa, Tonga, Fiji, Australia, and New Zealand.

Misipeka is the son of the late Kelemete and Iolani Misipeka of Fagatogo.

Section: 
Local News
Tags: 
cotton bowl

item.title: PC Online Tidbits
item.description:
IT was the night before Christmas, when of all the places to speed around a bend from, this driver decided to speed into the drain just outside our office. An alcohol fuelled mishap that caused him to skid into our drain ready for our cameras on Christmas coverage operations. Only thing going for him this Christmas was the cops eventually letting him off the hook to recover what looked like a very brand new slick ride now wrecked beyond recognition. We hope the cops are not as forgiving of other naughty motorists tonight.

The post PC Online Tidbits appeared first on Post Courier.
item.source:markdown:
![](https://www.postcourier.com.pg/wp-content/uploads/2024/04/TIDBITS-FEATURED-PIC.png?w=800)

item.title: Christmas eve Crash in Konedobu
item.description:
While police reported an almost peaceful Christmas Eve, a lone driver heading home crashed into a drain right in front of PNG’s Nambawan Daily Newspaper, the Post Courier, at Konedobu.

The driver, reportedly under the influence of alcohol and having fallen asleep at the wheel, lost control of the vehicle.

item.title: “Nation Building in Action”: PM Marape credits IRC and Infrastructure for strong 2025 finish
item.description:
Prime Minister James Marape has used the lead-up to Christmas 2025—the 50th Christmas since Papua New Guinea became a sovereign nation—to thank citizens, public servants and international partners, while outlining major economic achievements and reforms that will shape the country’s next chapter beyond its Golden Jubilee.

In a press conference, Prime Minister Marape expressed appreciation to Papua New Guineans across the country for their patience, resilience and cooperation throughout what he described as a demanding but ultimately successful year.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post “Nation Building in Action”: PM Marape credits IRC and Infrastructure for strong 2025 finish appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: Thieves using taxis to infiltrate Gerehu 3A as community watch thwarts new crime tactics
item.description:
Community leaders in Gerehu 3A are sounding the alarm on a sophisticated new tactic being used by car thieves, even as local volunteer efforts successfully drive down overall crime rates. According to community leader Penny Son, criminals have moved away from traditional methods and are now using hired taxis to infiltrate the neighborhood undetected.

These suspects reportedly use the cabs to scout for target vehicles and execute thefts, attempting to blend in with normal traffic to bypass security.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Thieves using taxis to infiltrate Gerehu 3A as community watch thwarts new crime tactics appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: Upper Highlands welcome Christmas power outage
item.description:
The residents across the Upper Highlands region are facing a Christmas without electricity following a major system failure.

Papua New Guinea Power Limited (PPL) has confirmed that the 507 Main Exporting Transmission Line, which runs from Himitovi to the Upper Highlands, has developed a "permanent fault." This has resulted in a complete supply isolation for the entire regional network.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Upper Highlands welcome Christmas power outage appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: Trump administration orders nearly 30 US ambassadors to leave their posts

item.title: Trump’s AI hiring campaign draws interest from 25,000 hopefuls
item.description: WASHINGTON — Roughly 25,000 people have ​expressed ‌interest in joining the ‌Trump administration’s cadre of engineers known as Tech Force, a senior Trump administration official said on Tuesday, as the ‍U.S. government looks to install staff with artificial intelligence expertise in federal roles. The Trump administration will use that ​list to recruit software and ​data engineers, in addition to other tech roles, said Scott Kupor, director of the U.S. Office of ‍Personnel Management, in a post on X. ​Reuters could not independently verify the 25,000 figure. The interested candidates will compete for 1,000 spots in the first Tech Force cohort. The recruits will spend two years working on technology projects inside federal agencies, including the Departments of Homeland Security, Veterans Affairs, and Justice, among other government offices, Kupor said previously.
item.source:markdown: WASHINGTON — Roughly 25,000 people have ​expressed ‌interest in joining the ‌Trump administration’s cadre of engineers known as Tech Force, a senior Trump administration official said on Tuesday, as the ‍U.S. government looks to install staff with artificial intelligence expertise in federal roles. The Trump administration will use that ​list to recruit software and ​data engineers, in addition to other tech roles, said Scott Kupor, director of the U.S. Office of ‍Personnel Management, in a post on X. ​Reuters could not independently verify the 25,000 figure. The interested candidates will compete for 1,000 spots in the first Tech Force cohort. The recruits will spend two years working on technology projects inside federal agencies, including the Departments of Homeland Security, Veterans Affairs, and Justice, among other government offices, Kupor said previously.

item.title: Obituaries for December 24
item.description: Genevieve “Gennie” Parages Delos Santos, 90, of Pahoa died Nov. 22 at Pali Momi Medical Center in Aiea, Oahu. Born in Honolulu, she was a retired public schools educational assistant. Visitation 9-10 a.m. Tuesdau, Jan. 26, at Dodo Mortuary Chapel. Funeral service at 10 a.m. Burial to follow at East Hawaii Veterans Cemetery No. 2 in Hilo. Casual attire. Online condolences: dodomortuary.com. Survived by son, Alfred “Randy” Delos Santos of Pahoa; daughters, Dona (Jaime) Florendo Jr. of Pahoa, Laura (Russell) Chang of Ewa Beach, Oahu, and Stephanie (George) Camarillo Jr. of Hilo; brother, Ronald “Steven” (Estelle) Parages of Ewa Beach; daughter-in-law, Princess Negrana of Pahoa; 11 grandchildren and 10 great-grandchildren; nephews and nieces. Arrangements by Dodo Mortuary.
item.source:markdown: Genevieve “Gennie” Parages Delos Santos, 90, of Pahoa died Nov. 22 at Pali Momi Medical Center in Aiea, Oahu. item.title: IRC appoints Sam Loi as Acting Commissioner General
item.description:
The Internal Revenue Commission (IRC) has announced the formal appointment of Commissioner of Tax, Mr Sam Loi, as Acting Commissioner General. The appointment was made by the National Executive Council and took effect on 17 December 2025. Mr Loi will serve in this capacity until a substantive appointment is finalized.

With this appointment, all statutory powers and functions vested in the office of the Commissioner General under Papua New Guinea’s tax laws are now lawfully exercised by Mr Loi. The IRC emphasized that the transition will not affect taxpayers, tax agents, financial institutions, international partner agencies, or other stakeholders. Engagement with the Commission will continue as normal, with no changes to existing tax obligations, compliance requirements, or service arrangements.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post IRC appoints Sam Loi as Acting Commissioner General appeared first on Post Courier.
item.source:markdown:
![](https://www.postcourier.com.pg/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/feature-picture-3.png?w=800)
The Internal Revenue Commission (IRC) has announced the formal appointment of Commissioner of Tax, Mr Sam Loi, as Acting Commissioner General. The appointment was made by the National Executive Council and took effect on 17 December 2025. Mr Loi will serve in this capacity until a substantive appointment is finalized.
With this appointment, all statutory powers and functions vested in the office of the Commissioner General under Papua New Guinea’s tax laws are now lawfully exercised by Mr Loi. The IRC emphasized that the transition will not affect taxpayers, tax agents, financial institutions, international partner agencies, or other stakeholders. Engagement with the Commission will continue as normal, with no changes to existing tax obligations, compliance requirements, or service arrangements.

item.title: Air Niugini’s A220 first landing in Rabaul
item.description:
Air Niugini successfully operated its first Airbus A220-300 commercial service into Tokua airport, Rabaul, last Friday on 19 December, marking a major milestone in the airline’s fleet modernisation and domestic network expansion.

The flight, PX 202, departed Port Moresby at 08:36 am and arrived in Rabaul at 10:07 am, carrying 101 people travelling home for Christmas.  The aircraft was accorded a traditional water salute upon arrival in recognition of the milestone occasion.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Air Niugini’s A220 first landing in Rabaul appeared first on Post Courier.
