item.title: Law and order failures rooted in broken families, says Wau-Waria MP in Christmas message
item.description:
Member for Wau-Waria, Marsh Narewec, says law and order problems gripping Papua New Guinea, particularly in young districts like Wau-Waria, are the result of decades of neglect in education and the breakdown of family structures, warning that the cost is now being paid in lost lives, destroyed property, and growing insecurity.

In his Christmas message to the people of Papua New Guinea and Wau-Waria District, Mr Narewec described 2025 as one of the most challenging years for the infant district, with law and order remaining its biggest obstacle to development.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Law and order failures rooted in broken families, says Wau-Waria MP in Christmas message appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: Empowering women and building futures: The impact of CPL Foundation
item.description:
In 2025, the CPL Foundation continued its dedicated mission to uplift women and girls across Papua New Guinea, making a profound difference in their lives through targeted healthcare, education, economic empowerment, and community support.

With over K1 million invested, the foundation focused on four key areas. In the realm of health, they screened more than 1,180 women for cervical cancer, providing onsite treatment to 84% of HPV-positive cases.

item.title: Lae Central Police Station shows its age amid ongoing role as City’s Policing Hub
item.description:
The worn floorboards creak underfoot. A broken window lets in dust and heat. Ablution blocks serving both male and female cell areas are blocked and unusable. These are not conditions one would expect at the heart of policing in Papua New Guinea’s second-largest city, yet this is the daily reality at Lae Central Police Station.

The post Lae Central Police Station shows its age amid ongoing role as City’s Policing Hub appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: Kumura says ‘Light has just begun’ for Usino-Bundi-Gama
item.description:
Member for Usino-Bundi-Gama, Vincent Kumura, says his district is entering a new chapter of hope after years of neglect, as his government begins restoring basic services and rebuilding trust with local communities.

In his 2025 Christmas message, Mr Kumura said the past year marked the beginning of change for what he described as a “forgotten district”, stretching from the mountains of Bundi to the plains of Usino and Gama.

item.title: Battle of the Bands aims to inspire Markham Youth as Resource Centre Opens
item.description:
The Markham Smart Farmers Association will host its annual Battle of the Bands competition on 27 and 28 January 2026, bringing together organised youth groups from across the Markham district for a two-day community event.

The competition will be held at the Markham Smart Farmers Association Resource Centre and will coincide with the official opening of the centre on 28 January. Organizers say the event is designed to give young people a positive and structured space to express themselves through music.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

item.title: Democratic-led states sue to block US consumer watchdog’s defunding under Trump
item.description: A coalition of Democratic-led states filed ‌a lawsuit on Monday seeking to prevent President Donald Trump’s administration from defunding the U.S. Consumer Financial Protection Bureau by refusing to request money from the Federal Reserve. Democratic attorneys general from 21 states and the District of Columbia filed the ‍lawsuit in federal court in Oregon, arguing that the administration’s decision not to seek additional funding for the U.S. consumer watchdog is unlawful and undermines Congress’ authority under the U.S. Constitution.
item.source:markdown: A coalition of Democratic-led states filed ‌a lawsuit on Monday seeking to prevent President Donald Trump’s administration from defunding the U.S. Consumer Financial Protection Bureau by refusing to request money from the Federal Reserve. Democratic attorneys general from 21 states and the District of Columbia filed the ‍lawsuit in federal court in Oregon, arguing that the administration’s decision not to seek additional funding for the U.S. consumer watchdog is unlawful and undermines Congress’ authority under the U.S. Constitution.

item.title: CBS postpones ‘60 Minutes’ report on El Salvador mega prison
item.description: NEW YORK — CBS News pulled ‌a “60 Minutes” report on a mega prison in El Salvador that houses hundreds of Venezuelan deportees sent by the U.S. just hours before its scheduled Sunday broadcast, saying it would air at a future time. “The broadcast lineup for tonight’s edition of 60 Minutes has been updated,” the program posted on social media on Sunday, three hours before it was slated to air. “Our report ‘Inside CECOT’ will air in a future broadcast.”

Not only did the burning log provide warmth and light, but also protected them from evil spirits.

The post Palau Ends 2025 Facing Fiscal, Ocean, and Social Pressures appeared first on Island Times News.
item.source:markdown:
By: L.N. Reklai Palau closes 2025 at a delicate junction where ocean policy, national sovereignty, and fiscal discipline are no longer abstract themes, but urgent, interconnected tests of the country’s future path. From the budget brinkmanship that twice brought government to the edge of shutdown, to high‑stakes debates over asylum deals and the marine sanctuary, \[…\]

item.title: Sir Brian Bell Foundation boosts youth ministry’s christmas outreach
item.description:
Christmas has come early for 'The Voice of the City Youth Ministry' following a generous donation from the Sir Brian Bell Foundation.

The founder of the ministry, Pastor Jack Walter Scott, officially received the items at the Brian Bell Plaza in Gordons. The newly established ministry aims to guide young people toward Christ through outreach programs in both urban and rural areas, identifying their needs and connecting them with available opportunities.

item.title: A decade of Staga Loving: Stagajah celebrates 10th anniversary
item.description:
The air at The Cosmopolitan was thick with nostalgia and pure, stark island rhythm last Friday night as the boys from Tokarara—the legendary Stagajah—celebrated a milestone that few reach and even fewer master: 10 solid years at the peak of the PNG music scene.

It wasn't just a concert; it was a masterclass in local groove, a journey from the dusty streets of Toka to the bright lights of the main stage, and the fans turned up in droves to witness the magic.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post A decade of Staga Loving: Stagajah celebrates 10th anniversary appeared first on Post Courier.
item.source:markdown:
![](https://www.postcourier.com.pg/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Stagajah-band-members-on-stage-during-their-10th-anniversary-concert.-Picture-by-Philemon-Kassman.png?w=800)
The air at The Cosmopolitan was thick with nostalgia and pure, stark island rhythm last Friday night as the boys from Tokarara—the legendary **Stagajah**—celebrated a milestone that few reach and even fewer master: 10 solid years at the peak of the PNG music scene.
It wasn't just a concert; it was a masterclass in local groove, a journey from the dusty streets of Toka to the bright lights of the main stage, and the fans turned up in droves to witness the magic.

item.title: ‘It was a PNGFA administrative blunder’
item.description:
Papua New Guinea Football Association (PNGFA) General Secretary Ahmjad Tekwie has taken full responsibility for a massive administrative failure that led to a "no-show" of Hekari United FC in the Premier Soccer League (PSL) third-place playoff.

The admission comes as Lae City FC Team Manager, Dennis Kosie Java, lashed out at the governing body and Hekari United FC, demanding both financial compensation and the suspension of the Port Moresby-based club.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post ‘It was a PNGFA administrative blunder’ appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: Marape unveils RESET@50 road map for next 20 years
item.description:
Papua New Guinea’s Golden Jubilee year has been marked not only by celebration but by a bold national reset. Prime Minister James Marape declared 2025 “one of the most consequential years in our history,” unveiling RESET@50, a long‑term roadmap designed to shape the nation’s next two decades.

Launched during the 50th anniversary of Independence, RESET@50 is framed as a generational project. It reviews the country’s first half‑century of nationhood and sets out a 20‑year plan (2025–2045) to strengthen governance, diversify the economy, and investment in human capital. “Fifty years is not the end of a journey. It is the moment we choose whether the next fifty will be better than the first,” Marape told citizens during the Jubilee reflections.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Marape unveils RESET@50 road map for next 20 years appeared first on Post Courier.
item.source:markdown:
![](https://www.postcourier.com.pg/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Lae-father-pleads-for-urgent-medical-help-as-breathing-sickness-worsens-33.png?w=800)

Launched during the 50th anniversary of Independence, RESET@50 is framed as a generational project. It reviews the country’s first half‑century of nationhood and sets out a 20‑year plan (2025–2045) to strengthen governance, diversify the economy, and investment in human capital. “Fifty years is not the end of a journey. It is the moment we choose whether the next fifty will be better than the first,” Marape told citizens during the Jubilee reflections.

item.title: Trump Administration recalls U.S. Ambassador to PNG among 29 in major “America First” Shake-Up
item.description:
The United States Ambassador to Papua New Guinea, Ann Marie Yastishock, is set to return home as part of a sweeping global recall of nearly 30 career diplomats by the Trump administration.

The move, confirmed by State Department insiders and first reported by the Associated Press and Newsweek, marks a significant expansion of President Donald Trump’s efforts to reshape the U.S. diplomatic corps during his second term.

item.description:

On Thursday, Governor Ramsey Pariwa acknowledged their resilience with a gesture that reinforced both tradition and hope for the future.

item.title: Madang teacher with disability receives motorized wheelchair from Governor
item.description:
A teacher who has dedicated more than a decade to educating children in Madang Province has received a Christmas gift that recognizes both his commitment and resilience.

Madang Governor,Ramsey Pariwa, personally presented Paul Mokrui with a brand-new motorized wheelchair at his home near Holy Spirit Primary School on Sunday.
The visit, which brought together Mokrui’s family, the school board chairman Christhoper Tomongo, and a handful of colleagues, was a moment of celebration and gratitude.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Madang teacher with disability receives motorized wheelchair from Governor appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: DPS holiday traffic enforcement officially launched
item.description:
By 
Samoa News staff
reporters@samoanews.com

Pago Pago, AMERICAN SAMOA — The Department of Public Safety officially launched its Holiday Enforcement initiative last Friday, marking the beginning of a focused effort to enhance road safety during the busy festive season. 

The sobriety roadblock was held in front of the CBT building in Nu’uuli, where close to 20 police officers were working. 

Commissioner of Public Safety Taaga Saite Moliga has announced the deployment of strategically placed roadblocks throughout the community to identify and evaluate drivers suspected of being under the influence of alcohol or drugs. 

These roadblocks will be strategically placed in response to real-time traffic patterns, focusing on high-traffic areas during peak travel periods to maximize visibility and effectiveness.

The last weekend before Christmas typically sees a surge in social gatherings, as numerous businesses host their annual holiday parties and end-of-year celebrations. This increase in festivities correlates with a heightened risk of impaired driving, underscoring the importance of vigilance during this critical time.

In response to these concerns, Commissioner Moliga is urging all community members to collaborate in fostering a culture of safety and awareness. The goal is to ensure the holiday season remains celebratory while minimizing the risks of impaired driving. 

To support this initiative, the Department of Public Safety will maintain its Holiday Enforcement program, which will extend through January 3, 2026. 

DPS says this initiative underscores its unwavering commitment to safeguarding public safety throughout the festive season and beyond, ensuring that all community members can enjoy a joyous, accident-free holiday period.

Section: 
Local News
Tags: 
DPS holiday traffic enforcement
item.source:markdown:
[![PS holiday traffic enforcement](https://www.samoanews.com/sites/default/files/styles/slideshow/public/field/image/holiday_traffic_enforcement.jpg?itok=PfxG-KTc)](https://www.samoanews.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_normal_image/public/field/image/holiday_traffic_enforcement.jpg?itok=zCP5iPHt)

item.title: PM Marape says 2026 will mark shift to AI-driven government
item.description:
Prime Minister James Marape says 2026 will mark a major transition year for Papua New Guinea, with the Government moving decisively to use artificial intelligence (AI) and information and communications technology (ICT) as core tools to strengthen governance, transparency and efficiency across the public service.

The Prime Minister said the Government will begin positioning AI as the “engine room” of government decision-making, supporting critical functions such as public service recruitment and selections, contract awards, project proposal assessments, policy development and the overall performance of government systems.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

item.description:

item.title: Trump set to expand immigration crackdown in 2026 despite brewing backlash
item.description: WASHINGTON — U.S. President Donald Trump is preparing ​for a more aggressive immigration crackdown in 2026 ‌with billions in new funding, including by raiding more workplaces — even as backlash builds ahead of next year’s midterm ‌elections. Trump has already surged immigration agents into major U.S. cities, where they swept through neighborhoods and clashed with residents. While federal agents this year conducted some high-profile raids on businesses, they largely avoided raiding farms, factories and other businesses that are economically important but known to employ immigrants without legal status. ICE and Border Patrol will get $170 billion in additional funds through September 2029 — a huge surge of funding over their existing annual budgets of about $19 billion after the Republican-controlled Congress passed a massive spending package in July. Administration officials say they ‍plan to hire thousands more agents, open new detention centers, pick up more immigrants in local jails and partner with outside companies to track down people without legal status.
item.source:markdown: WASHINGTON — U.S. President Donald Trump is preparing ​for a more aggressive immigration crackdown in 2026 ‌with billions in new funding, including by raiding more workplaces — even as backlash builds ahead of next year’s midterm ‌elections. Trump has already surged immigration agents into major U.S. cities, where they swept through neighborhoods and clashed with residents. While federal agents this year conducted some high-profile raids on businesses, they largely avoided raiding farms, factories and other businesses that are economically important but known to employ immigrants without legal status. ICE and Border Patrol will get $170 billion in additional funds through September 2029 — a huge surge of funding over their existing annual budgets of about $19 billion after the Republican-controlled Congress passed a massive spending package in July. Administration officials say they ‍plan to hire thousands more agents, open new detention centers, pick up more immigrants in local jails and partner with outside companies to track down people without legal status.

item.title: How the Supreme Court’s mail-in ballot ruling could affect voters
item.description: The Supreme Court is set to decide this term whether states can count mail-in ballots received after Election Day. The case centers on a law in Mississippi, but a total of about 18 states and territories accept such late-arriving ballots as long as they are postmarked by Election Day.

item.title: Japan prepares to restart world’s biggest nuclear plant, 15 years after Fukushima
item.description: NIIGATA, Japan — The Japanese region of Niigata is expected to endorse a ‌decision to restart the world’s largest nuclear power plant today, a watershed moment in the country’s pivot back to nuclear since the 2011 Fukushima disaster. Kashiwazaki-Kariwa, located about 220 km (136 miles) northwest of Tokyo, was among 54 reactors shut after a massive earthquake and tsunami crippled the Fukushima Daiichi plant in the worst nuclear disaster since Chernobyl. Since then, Japan has restarted 14 of ‍the 33 that remain operable, as it tries to wean itself off imported fossil fuels. Kashiwazaki-Kariwa will be the first operated by Tokyo Electric Power Co, which ran the doomed Fukushima plant.
item.source:markdown: NIIGATA, Japan — The Japanese region of Niigata is expected to endorse a ‌decision to restart the world’s largest nuclear power plant today, a watershed moment in the country’s pivot back to nuclear since the 2011 Fukushima disaster. item.title: NICTA announces release of Draft SIM Card Registration Regulation 2026
item.description:
The National Information and Communications Technology Authority (NICTA) of Papua New Guinea has announced the release of the Draft SIM Card Registration (Amendment and Consolidation) Regulation 2026 for public consultation. This initiative is being carried out under Sections 229 and 230 of the National Information and Communications Technology Act 2009, marking an important step in strengthening the country’s telecommunications framework.

Authorized by the acting CEO of NICTA Polume Lume, the proposed regulation seeks to update and consolidate the existing SIM Card Registration Regulation 2016. Key amendments include the integration of digital identity systems, enhanced identity verification processes, and stronger provisions for cybersecurity and data protection. These measures aim to ensure that SIM card registration is secure, reliable, and aligned with modern technological standards. Additionally, the draft introduces certification requirements for SIM registration agents, ensuring accountability and professionalism in the registration process. Recognizing the unique challenges faced in rural and remote areas, the regulation also outlines mechanisms for offline registration, making the process more accessible to communities across Papua New Guinea.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post NICTA announces release of Draft SIM Card Registration Regulation 2026 appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: Alcohol at Christmas
item.description:
There are no written records to indicate that, our ancestors had any knowledge about alcohol or alcohol beverages before contact with the Europeans in the 19th century.

In the 1800s up to1960, in both the German New Guinea and British Papua, the natives were barred from taking alcohol and it was in 1963 that the legislations were introduced to allow Papua New Guineans over 18 years of age to consume alcohol.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

In the 1800s up to1960, in both the German New Guinea and British Papua, the natives were barred from taking alcohol and it was in 1963 that the legislations were introduced to allow Papua New Guineans over 18 years of age to consume alcohol.

item.title: Obituaries for December 21
item.description: Tommy Denon Elisaga, 74, of Pahoa died Nov. 18 at Yukio Okutsu State Veterans Home in Hilo. Born in Papaaloa, he was a cafeteria cook at Ernest B. deSilva Elementary School, cafeteria supervisor at Kulani Correctional Facility, member of the former Hilo Door of Faith Church in Kaumana and U.S. Army veteran. Visitation 10 a.m-noon Saturday (Dec. 27) at Kaumana Drive Baptist Church. Memorial service at 11 a.m. Gathering to follow at the church. Urn committal services 11:30 a.m. Monday, Dec. 29, at East Hawaii Veterans Cemetery No. 2 Pavilion. Casual attire; no flowers. Survived by sons, Taddy (Belinda) Elisaga of Honolulu, Troye (Ruschelle) Elisaga of Washington state and Timothy (Janine) Elisaga of Kurtistown; daughter, Yarnell (Justin) Matsu of Keaau; brothers. Paul (Marlene) Elisaga of Kona and William Elisaga of Honolulu; sister, Violet Morales of Papaaloa; seven grandchildren; nieces and nephews. Arrangements by Dodo Mortuary.
item.source:markdown: Tommy Denon Elisaga, 74, of Pahoa died Nov. 18 at Yukio Okutsu State Veterans Home in Hilo. Born in Papaaloa, he was a cafeteria cook at Ernest B. deSilva Elementary School, cafeteria supervisor at Kulani Correctional Facility, member of the former Hilo Door of Faith Church in Kaumana and U.S. Army veteran. Visitation 10 a.m-noon Saturday (Dec. 27) at Kaumana Drive Baptist Church. Memorial service at 11 a.m. Gathering to follow at the church. Urn committal services 11:30 a.m. Monday, Dec. 29, at East Hawaii Veterans Cemetery No. 2 Pavilion. Casual attire; no flowers. Survived by sons, Taddy (Belinda) Elisaga of Honolulu, Troye (Ruschelle) Elisaga of Washington state and Timothy (Janine) Elisaga of Kurtistown; daughter, Yarnell (Justin) Matsu of Keaau; brothers. item.title: Volcano Watch: One year of Kilauea’s episodic summit fountaining
item.description: On Dec. 23, 2024, a unique eruption began in Kilauea’s Halema‘uma‘u crater, with a style of activity not seen for nearly 40 years. The eruption, characterized by high lava-fountaining episodes, has continued for nearly a year. Hawaii Volcanoes National Park visitors see remarkable views, but the latest episode reminds us how quickly hazards associated with this dynamic activity can change.
item.source:markdown: On Dec. 23, 2024, a unique eruption began in Kilauea’s Halema‘uma‘u crater, with a style of activity not seen for nearly 40 years. item.title: ‘Gerehu for Gerehu’ volunteers secure community during festive season
item.description:
Members of the "Gerehu for Gerehu" (G4G) initiative are providing a safe environment for residents and visitors in Port Moresby this festive season.

G4G is a community-led crime prevention initiative that has operated on a voluntary basis for nearly three years. Its mission is to bridge the gap between formal law enforcement and community engagement.

item.title: Ela Beach Christmas lights spark boom for local vendors
item.description:
The dazzling Christmas light display at Ela Beach has transformed the beachfront into a vibrant night market, providing a festive boost for local informal traders.

Nearly 50 mothers and youths have set around the Christmas light "hotspots," turning the beach into a bustling hub for holiday commerce. Vendors told Post-Courier Online that the massive crowds drawn to the decorations have significantly boosted their sales, creating a unique seasonal opportunity for small-scale entrepreneurs.

item.title: National Doctors Association opposes reappointment of Pascoe Kase as Health Secretary
item.description:
The National Doctors Association (NDA) of Papua New Guinea has expressed grave concern regarding reports of the National Executive Council’s (NEC) decision to appoint Mr. Pascoe Kase as the permanent Secretary for Health.

NDA President Dr. James Naipao stated that this decision has triggered widespread unease among frontline health workers and development partners, threatening the fragile reforms currently underway within the national health system.

item.title: Prime Minister Marape pays tribute to late works minister Solan Mirisim at Telefomin funeral service
item.description:
Prime Minister James Marape said Telefomin District has lost one of its most productive and committed leaders since Independence in 1975, following the passing of Solan Mirisim, Member for Telefomin and Minister for Works and Highways.

Speaking at the funeral service, the Prime Minister said Telefomin has, over many years,
produced some of Papua New Guinea’s finest leaders, public servants and police officers,
and late Mirisim stood among the very best of his generation.

item.title: Better jobs, better skills: DHERST partners with TAFE Queensland for TVET excellence
item.description:
The Department of Higher Education, Research, Science, and Technology (DHERST) is set to enhance governance, teacher training, curriculum development, and infrastructure across Technical and Vocational Education and Training (TVET) colleges in Papua New Guinea.

Following a National Executive Council directive to address challenges within the sector, DHERST through the Improved TVET for Employment (ITVET4E) project has signed a K27 million contract for a Technical Support Team (TST) with TAFE Queensland.

item.title: Parkop hails governor’s cup as premier talent pipeline
item.description:
The annual Governor’s Cup has solidified its reputation as the premier talent identification platform in the National Capital District following the official launch of the 2025 festival in Port Moresby.

During the launch, Governor Powes Parkop highlighted the tournament's proven track record of elevating local athletes to the international stage, specifically pointing to the rise of star halfback Judah Rimbu. Rimbu, a direct product of the Governor’s Cup, successfully progressed to the PNG Hunters and played in England, serving as a powerful testament to the tournament's role in professional player development.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Parkop hails governor’s cup as premier talent pipeline appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: Governor’s Cup launch prioritises city safety and unity for festive season
item.description:
Governor Powes Parkop has officially launched the annual Governor’s Cup Festival, framing the sporting extravaganza as a critical strategy for maintaining law and order across the capital throughout the Christmas and New Year period.

Joined by high-ranking officials, including NCD and central Acting Commissioner of Police Ben Turi, as well as representatives from the Australian Federal Police, Governor Parkop underscored the tournament’s role as more than just a competition.

item.title: Parkop pledges K100,000 for netball as governor’s Cup Expands
item.description:
National Capital District Governor Powes Parkop has announced a record-breaking investment in women’s sports as part of the 2025-2026 Governor’s Cup Festival, headlined by a massive K100,000 prize pool for the tournament’s inaugural netball competition.

A total of K100,000 will be distributed across three distinct categories: the Cup, the Plate, and the Bowls. The top-tier Cup division will see K50,000 shared among the first, second, and third-place finishers, while the Plate category offers a K30,000 prize pool, and the Bowls division provides K20,000, both also split between the top three teams.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Parkop pledges K100,000 for netball as governor’s Cup Expands appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: Mixed start for Morobe Tutumang: 21 Sworn In, 16 Walk Out in Protest
item.description:
A total of 21 presidents-elect took their oaths as Morobe Tutumang members, while 16 others walked out in protest over the delay, as the ceremony did not begin until 3:40pm and ran into late Friday evening.

Flight delays between Port Moresby and Lae caused the late arrival of Acting Governor Rainbo Paita, resulting in the ceremony convening as late as 5pm.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

item.title: A new wing for the Holidays: Air Niugini’s Airbus A220 to stabilize festive travel
item.description:
As the Christmas travel rush reaches its peak, Air Niugini has delivered a significant "gift" to the traveling public. The airline officially welcomed its latest fleet addition, the Airbus A220 (registered as P2-PGC).

At the arrival of the third new aircraft on Thursday, December 18, 2025, Acting Chief Operating Officer Captain Samiu Taufa says the arrival of the new aircraft is about meeting the human needs of a nation and is timely to restore reliability to Papua New Guinea’s skies during the busiest time of the year.

item.title: Morobe Businessman donates K25,000 to Police for Christmas
item.description:
A Morobe businessman, Justin Parker, has recognized the dedication of police officers in the province by handing over K25,000 in cash vouchers to support them during the Christmas season.

“Every business is having a very hard time, but as a citizen of Lae and Morobe, I can say we have the best police force in the country,” Mr Parker said. “Whenever you call the police for help, they are always on alert and usually the first on the scene. That is something to be proud of as a Morobe citizen.”

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

item.title: PNG indigenous business women claim their right to respect
item.description:
I am a woman in business in Papua New Guinea. This is my 11th year managing a small business. The business focuses on sharing our people's journeys and cultures through prints on fabric and women's clothing items, such as meri blouses / kolos, and PNG-themed gifts, including handmade crafts.

The post PNG indigenous business women claim their right to respect appeared first on Post Courier.
item.source:markdown:

item.title: Boys & Girls Clubs of American Samoa garner two prestigious awards
item.description:
Pago Pago, AMERICAN SAMOA  — The Boys & Girls Clubs of American Samoa, a leader in youth development and leadership programs, was recently awarded two prestigious awards from Boys & Girls Clubs of America (BGCA) at the Pacific Region Leadership Conference that was held in Las Vegas, Nevada.

The “100 Club Award” is a recognition given by BGCA to local clubs that are 100% committed to the goals of “Operation Impact” and have demonstrated dedication to implementing this strategic plan and setting bold goals for their future and the youth they serve. Operation Impact was launched in 2024 and key aspects include increasing membership; growing teen participation; boosting average daily attendance; and creating exceptional Club experiences for every young person.

At a luncheon held for Board Members and Executive Leadership, BGCA Executive Vice President and Chief Operations Officer Lorraine Orr presented the “S.O.A.R. Award”, which is the highest level of recognition given to an organization’s Board of Directors who achieve Gold status for three consecutive years. This distinguished accolade not only recognizes sustained excellence in board engagement but also serves as a testament to the organization’s unwavering commitment to driving the Boys & Girls Club’s mission forward.

This past January, the Chairman of the BGCAS Board of Directors and Chief Volunteer Officer, Mrs. Mary A.T. Tulafono was honored with an official appointment as an “Operation Impact Ambassador” for the Pacific Region. Mrs. Tulafono was formally recognized at the Opening Session of the Pacific Region Leadership Conference for her role and contributions to the BGCA Movement. Mrs. Tulafono, along with BGCAS Executive Director, Sailipea Kennison Barber, accepted both awards on behalf of the local organization.

 

Section: 
Local News
Tags: 
e Boys & Girls Clubs of American Samoa
item.source:markdown:
[![hief Volunteer Officer, Mrs. Mary A.T. Tulafono with presenter](https://www.samoanews.com/sites/default/files/styles/slideshow/public/field/image/100_award_final.jpg?itok=4EnYJw5R)](https://www.samoanews.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_normal_image/public/field/image/100_award_final.jpg?itok=A6JULl6Q)

The “100 Club Award” is a recognition given by BGCA to local clubs that are 100% committed to the goals of “Operation Impact” and have demonstrated dedication to implementing this strategic plan and setting bold goals for their future and the youth they serve. Operation Impact was launched in 2024 and key aspects include increasing membership; growing teen participation; boosting average daily attendance; and creating exceptional Club experiences for every young person.
At a luncheon held for Board Members and Executive Leadership, BGCA Executive Vice President and Chief Operations Officer Lorraine Orr presented the “S.O.A.R. Award”, which is the highest level of recognition given to an organization’s Board of Directors who achieve Gold status for three consecutive years. This distinguished accolade not only recognizes sustained excellence in board engagement but also serves as a testament to the organization’s unwavering commitment to driving the Boys & Girls Club’s mission forward.
This past January, the Chairman of the BGCAS Board of Directors and Chief Volunteer Officer, Mrs. Mary A.T. Tulafono was honored with an official appointment as an “Operation Impact Ambassador” for the Pacific Region. Mrs. Tulafono was formally recognized at the Opening Session of the Pacific Region Leadership Conference for her role and contributions to the BGCA Movement. Mrs. Tulafono, along with BGCAS Executive Director, Sailipea Kennison Barber, accepted both awards on behalf of the local organization.

item.title: City wardens deploy for “Operation Christmas” following intensive tactical training
item.description:
The National Capital District (NCD) is set for a safer festive season as City Wardens return to the frontline following a rigorous two-month intensive training program at Goldie River, Central Province with the military and police trainers.

The wardens, a flagship initiative of NCD Governor Powes Parkop and the National Capital District Commission (NCDC), are now fully prepared to integrate with the Royal Papua New Guinea Constabulary (RPNGC) for a joint Christmas and New Year security operation.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

item.title: Obituaries for December 19
item.description: Patrick Ian Bagobe, 27, of Kailua-Kona died Nov. 8 at Kona Community Hospital. Born in Aliminos, Pangasinan, Philippines, he was a restaurant cook. Visitation 9-10 a.m. Saturday, Dec. 20, at St. Michael’s Catholic Church in Kailua-Kona. Mass at 10 a.m. Burial will be in Rosales, Pangasinan, Philippines. Survived by father, Fredie Launico of Kailua-Kona; mother, Analiz Bagobe of Rosales, Pangasinan, Philippines; brothers, Godofredo Launico and John Emil Lauico of Rosales, Pangasinan, Philippines; grandmother, Adela Launico of Pangasinan, Philippines; cousins, aunts and uncles. Arrangements by Dodo Mortuary and Oahu Mortuary.

item.title: Trump calls for moon landing in 2028, moon bases thereafter
item.description: WASHINGTON — President ‌Donald Trump enshrined the U.S. goal to put humans back on the moon by 2028 and defend space from weapon threats in a sweeping executive order issued on Thursday, the first major space policy move of his administration’s second term. The order, issued hours after billionaire private astronaut and former SpaceX customer Jared Isaacman was ‍sworn in as NASA’s 15th administrator, also reorganized national space policy coordination under Trump’s chief science adviser, Michael Kratsios.
item.source:markdown: WASHINGTON — President ‌Donald Trump enshrined the U.S. goal to put humans back on the moon by 2028 and defend space from weapon threats in a sweeping executive order issued on Thursday, the first major space policy move of his administration’s second term. The order, issued hours after billionaire private astronaut and former SpaceX customer Jared Isaacman was ‍sworn in as NASA’s 15th administrator, also reorganized national space policy coordination under Trump’s chief science adviser, Michael Kratsios.

item.title: Inflation unexpectedly slowed to 2.7% in November
item.description: U.S. inflation eased in November in what economists said likely reflected distortions caused by the government shutdown, creating an uncertain picture for the Federal Reserve as it simultaneously contends with rising unemployment.
item.source:markdown: U.S. inflation eased in November in what economists said likely reflected distortions caused by the government shutdown, creating an uncertain picture for the Federal Reserve as it simultaneously contends with rising unemployment.

item.title: Seven dead in fatal plane crash including former NASCAR driver Greg Biffle
item.description: Seven people were killed Thursday in the crash of a Cessna 550 business jet in Statesville, North Carolina, including former NASCAR driver Greg Biffle, ‍NASCAR said.
item.source:markdown: Seven people were killed Thursday in the crash of a Cessna 550 business jet in Statesville, North Carolina, including former NASCAR driver Greg Biffle, ‍NASCAR said.

item.title: The Kennedy Center board votes to add ‘Trump’ to its name, drawing backlash
item.description: WASHINGTON — The board of the ‌John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, which President Donald Trump filled with allies during a broad takeover earlier this year, decided on Thursday to add Trump’s name to the institution, horrifying Democrats and raising questions about the legality of the change. Trump, a Republican who is serving his second term as president, has been eager to put his stamp on Washington and his name on buildings. The ‍administration recently added his name to the United States Institute of Peace building near the White House.
item.source:markdown: WASHINGTON — The board of the ‌John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, which President Donald Trump filled with allies during a broad takeover earlier this year, decided on Thursday to add Trump’s name to the institution, horrifying Democrats and raising questions about the legality of the change. Trump, a Republican who is serving his second term as president, has been eager to put his stamp on Washington and his name on buildings. The ‍administration recently added his name to the United States Institute of Peace building near the White House.

item.title: Meeting to discuss Hilo wilderness park draws large crowd
item.description: About 100 people attended a community meeting Wednesday night at Hilo High School concerning a proposal by state Rep. Matthias Kusch to create a wilderness park on 283 acres of land on Akolea Road in Kaumana.
item.source:markdown: About 100 people attended a community meeting Wednesday night at Hilo High School concerning a proposal by state Rep. Matthias Kusch to create a wilderness park on 283 acres of land on Akolea Road in Kaumana.

item.title: First responders honored in Waimea
item.description: The 9th annual “Mahalo First Responders” dinner took place on Nov. 21, with three special honorees shining a spotlight on Waimea safety, rural health care, and the lifeguards who get people back to shore safely.
item.source:markdown: The 9th annual “Mahalo First Responders” dinner took place on Nov. 21, with three special honorees shining a spotlight on Waimea safety, rural health care, and the lifeguards who get people back to shore safely.

item.title: Bridge classes offered in Kona
item.description: Kona Bridge Club, an American Contract Bridge League affiliate, is offering classes in basic Bridge in January. Any members of the public, of any age, are invited to learn this thoughtful and interesting game, and no prior experience with bridge is needed.

item.title: Australia to crack down on hate speech after Bondi attack
item.description: SYDNEY — Prime Minister Anthony Albanese of Australia announced on Thursday new measures to combat antisemitism, including legislation that would “crack down on those who spread hate, division and radicalization.”
item.source:markdown: SYDNEY — Prime Minister Anthony Albanese of Australia announced on Thursday new measures to combat antisemitism, including legislation that would “crack down on those who spread hate, division and radicalization.”

item.title: Pope Leo names Illinois bishop to replace Cardinal Dolan in New York
item.description: Pope Leo XIV on Thursday named an Illinois bishop to replace the powerful conservative Cardinal Timothy Dolan as leader of New York City’s Roman Catholic archdiocese, a selection that signals his embrace of a more mild and unifying style after the political upheaval of Pope Francis’ papacy, while preserving the spirit of the late pope’s reforms.
item.source:markdown: Pope Leo XIV on Thursday named an Illinois bishop to replace the powerful conservative Cardinal Timothy Dolan as leader of New York City’s Roman Catholic archdiocese, a selection that signals his embrace of a more mild and unifying style after the political upheaval of Pope Francis’ papacy, while preserving the spirit of the late pope’s reforms.

item.title: Trump moves to end gender-related care for minors, threatening hospitals that offer it
item.description: The federal government on Thursday acted to put an end to gender-related care for minors across the nation, threatening to pull federal funding from any hospital that offered such treatment.
item.source:markdown: The federal government on Thursday acted to put an end to gender-related care for minors across the nation, threatening to pull federal funding from any hospital that offered such treatment.

item.title: Victim in Wild Ginger Inn fire identified
item.description: Police have identified the man who died in the Oct. 22 structure fire at Wild Ginger Inn on Puueo Street in Hilo as 66-year-old Gerald James O’Grady.

item.title: Daru Airport closed following Cessna Hard Landing
item.description:
The National Airports Corporation (NAC) has confirmed that an aircraft incident occurred at Daru Airport today, Friday, 19 December 2025, forcing a temporary suspension of flight operations.

The aircraft, a Cessna 188, was arriving from Horn Island at approximately 0830 hours when it experienced a hard landing. The impact resulted in the collapse of the aircraft’s front right wheel, causing the plane to become disabled at the runway edge within the touchdown zone of Runway 14.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Daru Airport closed following Cessna Hard Landing appeared first on Post Courier.
item.source:markdown:
![](https://www.postcourier.com.pg/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Aircraft-Incident-at-Daru-Airport-–-Runway-closure-and-pavement-repairs-underway.png?w=800)
The National Airports Corporation (NAC) has confirmed that an aircraft incident occurred at **Daru Airport** today, Friday, 19 December 2025, forcing a temporary suspension of flight operations.
The aircraft, a _Cessna 188,_ was arriving from Horn Island at approximately **0830 hours** when it experienced a hard landing. The impact resulted in the collapse of the aircraft’s front right wheel, causing the plane to become disabled at the runway edge within the touchdown zone of Runway 14.

item.title: Governor Parkop launches special christmas security operation for NCD and Central
item.description:
Governor for the National Capital District (NCD), Powes Parkop, officially launched the 2025 NCD and central province Christmas and New Year police operations today, calling for a "peaceful, joyful, and inclusive" festive season as the nation concludes its historic 50th anniversary year.

Addressing a major parade of the Royal Papua New Guinea Constabulary (RPNGC), Parkop was joined by Assistant Commissioner of Police (ACP) Ben Turi and Metropolitan Superintendent Warrick Simatab.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

item.title: NCD Governor calls for peace and security deliverance this festive season
item.description:
The NCD Governor, Powes Parkop, has advised the Royal Papua New Guinea Constabulary (RPNGC) and other security initiatives to deliver peace and security to all residents within NCD and Central province.

In his address at the launching of the Christmas and New Year operations held today at Unagi Oval, Port Moresby, Parkop highlighted the crucial need for security and peace in the city and nationwide.

item.title: Rao: Empowering Pacific Leadership through HR Excellence and Strategic Learning
item.description:
Muneshwari Sayal Rao, a distinguished Human Resources professional, is making a significant impact on Fiji’s corporate and organisational landscape by leveraging her extensive experience in people management, leadership development, and culture-building.

Throughout her career, Rao has guided teams through major periods of change, including organisational restructures, shifts in leadership direction, and the implementation of new systems and performance expectations. She has been instrumental in helping staff navigate uncertainty, strengthening communication, clarifying priorities, and ensuring teams have the capability and support to adapt.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Rao: Empowering Pacific Leadership through HR Excellence and Strategic Learning appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: In White House speech, Trump highlights victories amid sinking approval ratings
item.description: WASHINGTON — In a rare evening address from the White House, President Donald Trump boasted on Wednesday of his accomplishments and blamed his Democratic predecessor for soaring consumer prices as his party braces for a tough midterm election next year. “Eleven months ago, I inherited a mess, and I’m fixing it,” Trump said in a speech that lasted less than 20 minutes and was delivered at rapid-fire pace.
item.source:markdown: WASHINGTON — In a rare evening address from the White House, President Donald Trump boasted on Wednesday of his accomplishments and blamed his Democratic predecessor for soaring consumer prices as his party braces for a tough midterm election next year. “Eleven months ago, I inherited a mess, and I’m fixing it,” Trump said in a speech that lasted less than 20 minutes and was delivered at rapid-fire pace.

item.title: Sweeping US defense bill passes, with Ukraine, Venezuela provisions defying Trump
item.description: WASHINGTON — The U.S. Senate voted overwhelmingly on Wednesday to advance a $901 billion bill setting policy for the Pentagon, sending the massive piece of legislation to the White House, which has said President Donald Trump will sign it into law. The fiscal 2026 National Defense Authorization Act, or NDAA, is a compromise between separate measures passed earlier this year in the House of Representatives and Senate. It authorizes a record $901 billion in annual military spending, with a 4% pay raise for the troops. It also authorizes reforms to the system for acquiring military equipment and includes efforts to boost competitiveness with U.S. archrivals China and Russia.
item.source:markdown: WASHINGTON — The U.S. Senate voted overwhelmingly on Wednesday to advance a $901 billion bill setting policy for the Pentagon, sending the massive piece of legislation to the White House, which has said President Donald Trump will sign it into law. The fiscal 2026 National Defense Authorization Act, or NDAA, is a compromise between separate measures passed earlier this year in the House of Representatives and Senate. It authorizes a record $901 billion in annual military spending, with a 4% pay raise for the troops. It also authorizes reforms to the system for acquiring military equipment and includes efforts to boost competitiveness with U.S. archrivals China and Russia.

item.title: US Senate unanimously approves military helicopter safety legislation
item.description: WASHINGTON — The U.S. Senate unanimously passed legislation Wednesday to toughen military helicopter safety rules and rescind a provision in the annual defense bill that critics said would have weakened aviation safety. Republican Senate Commerce Committee chair Ted Cruz on Wednesday won unanimous consent to approve a revised version of legislation that would require aircraft operators by the end of 2031 to equip their fleets with an automatic dependent surveillance-broadcast system, also known as ADS-B. The bill, co-sponsored by Democratic Senator Maria Cantwell, also boosts oversight of commercial jet and helicopter traffic and flight routes near commercial airports. Aviation safety in the Washington area has come under scrutiny after the January 29 collision near Reagan Washington National Airport of an American Airlines regional jet and Army Black Hawk helicopter killed 67 people. Cruz said the bill will save lives and “be a fitting way to honor the lives of those lost nearly one year ago over the Potomac River.”
item.source:markdown: WASHINGTON — The U.S. Senate unanimously passed legislation Wednesday to toughen military helicopter safety rules and rescind a provision in the annual defense bill that critics said would have weakened aviation safety. Republican Senate Commerce Committee chair Ted Cruz on Wednesday won unanimous consent to approve a revised version of legislation that would require aircraft operators by the end of 2031 to equip their fleets with an automatic dependent surveillance-broadcast system, also known as ADS-B. The bill, co-sponsored by Democratic Senator Maria Cantwell, also boosts oversight of commercial jet and helicopter traffic and flight routes near commercial airports. Aviation safety in the Washington area has come under scrutiny after the January 29 collision near Reagan Washington National Airport of an American Airlines regional jet and Army Black Hawk helicopter killed 67 people. Cruz said the bill will save lives and “be a fitting way to honor the lives of those lost nearly one year ago over the Potomac River.”

item.title: Trump prosecutor Jack Smith defends probes in House testimony
item.description: WASHINGTON — Jack Smith, the former U.S. Justice Department special counsel who brought two now-dropped criminal cases against President Donald Trump, defended his investigation before a House of Representatives panel on Wednesday, telling lawmakers that the basis for the prosecutions “rests entirely with President Trump and his actions.” Smith gave private testimony to the Republican-controlled House Judiciary Committee following months of disclosures from Trump appointees at the Justice Department and Republican lawmakers intended to discredit Smith’s probe and bolster Trump’s claims that the cases were an abuse of the legal system. Smith and his team secured indictments in 2023, accusing Trump of illegally retaining classified documents following his first term in office and plotting to overturn his defeat in the 2020 election. Smith dropped both cases after Trump won the 2024 election, citing a Justice Department policy against prosecuting a sitting president.
item.source:markdown: WASHINGTON — Jack Smith, the former U.S. Justice Department special counsel who brought two now-dropped criminal cases against President Donald Trump, defended his investigation before a House of Representatives panel on Wednesday, telling lawmakers that the basis for the prosecutions “rests entirely with President Trump and his actions.” Smith gave private testimony to the Republican-controlled House Judiciary Committee following months of disclosures from Trump appointees at the Justice Department and Republican lawmakers intended to discredit Smith’s probe and bolster Trump’s claims that the cases were an abuse of the legal system. Smith and his team secured indictments in 2023, accusing Trump of illegally retaining classified documents following his first term in office and plotting to overturn his defeat in the 2020 election. Smith dropped both cases after Trump won the 2024 election, citing a Justice Department policy against prosecuting a sitting president.

item.title: Trump administration plans to break up premier weather and climate research center
item.description: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration said it will be dismantling the National Center for Atmospheric Research in Colorado, one of the world’s leading Earth science research institutions.

item.title: US Senate confirms private astronaut, Musk ally Jared Isaacman as NASA chief
item.description: WASHINGTON — The U.S. Senate on Wednesday confirmed billionaire private astronaut Jared Isaacman to become President Donald Trump’s NASA administrator, making an advocate of Mars missions and a former associate of SpaceX CEO Elon Musk the space agency’s 15th leader. The vote on Isaacman, who Trump removed and then renamed as NASA administrator nominee this year, passed 67-30, two weeks after he told senators in his second hearing that NASA must pick up the pace in beating China back to the moon this decade.
item.source:markdown: WASHINGTON — The U.S. Senate on Wednesday confirmed billionaire private astronaut Jared Isaacman to become President Donald Trump’s NASA administrator, making an advocate of Mars missions and a former associate of SpaceX CEO Elon Musk the space agency’s 15th leader. item.title: Kimbe market transforms into ‘Beacon of Hope’ with festive christmas display
item.description:
THE  heart of Kimbe town in West New Britain province has been transformed into a festive wonderland as the Kimbe Main Market officially unveiled its Christmas lights and holiday program, aimed at bringing a sense of peace and celebration to the residents.

Led by the Kimbe Market Authority (KMA), the initiative is a collaborative effort to shift the local narrative from negativity to one of community spirit and hope. Market Manager Diane Amaka Mandui Mirio, Operations Monitoring Officer Benjamin Manjobie, and OIC Operations Baltimore Mandui spearheaded the project alongside local partners.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

item.title: New era for PNG Skills: TAFE Queensland partners with DHERST in K27M landmark deal
item.description:
The Department of Higher Education, Research, Science and Technology (DHERST) has officially partnered with TAFE Queensland to transform the nation’s TVET sector in a major boost for the future of technical education in Papua New Guinea.

Following a rigorous competitive bidding process involving eight firms, TAFE Queensland emerged as the successful partner to lead the Technical Support Team (TST) for the Improved TVET for Employment (ITVET4E) project.

item.title: PNG asserts sustained tackling of corruption at global forum
item.description:
Effectively combating corruption at all levels and on a sustained basis is a key priority, Richard Masere, MP, Minister of State - Ministry of Administrative Services, told delegates from 192 countries at the Conference of States Parties (COSP11) on the UN Convention against Corruption in Doha, Qatar.

“We recognise that the country’s security, stability and sustainable development future must and cannot be held back by corruption unabated,” said Minister Masere, who leads Papua New Guinea’s delegation of 21 Government, civil society, ICAC and judicial representatives, whose attendance is supported by UNODC, the guardian of the UNCAC, the PNG Government, and UNDP.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post PNG asserts sustained tackling of corruption at global forum appeared first on Post Courier.

“We recognise that the country’s security, stability and sustainable development future must and cannot be held back by corruption unabated,” said Minister Masere, who leads Papua New Guinea’s delegation of 21 Government, civil society, ICAC and judicial representatives, whose attendance is supported by UNODC, the guardian of the UNCAC, the PNG Government, and UNDP.

item.title: Porgera-Paiela MP announces school fee assistance program
item.description:
Christmas has come as a timely blessing for students and families in Porgera-Paiela, with the Open Member of Parliament, Gidron Maso Karipe, announcing the rollout of a School Fee Assistance programme for eligible tertiary students from the Porgera-Paiela and Maip Mulitaka areas.

The initiative continues the long-standing commitment to education established under the late Maso Karipe and is aimed at easing the financial burden on families by supporting students pursuing higher education within Papua New Guinea.

item.title: Air Niugini targets Qantas on Sydney route with new A220 fleet
item.description:
Air Niugini is positioning its new Airbus A220 aircraft as a key strategic tool for expanding its international reach and increasing market competition, particularly on the busy Australian routes. The A220s are seen as vital to the future of the nation's aviation sector, facilitating the movement of business people, workers, and students, and opening up tourism and shipping goods to market.

The added advantage of the A220 is its versatility; it carries more passengers and cargo than the older Fokker aircraft and has the range necessary for extensive travel.

item.title: Understanding Corrupt Conduct and ICAC’s Jurisdiction
item.description:
It has been an inspiring and rewarding journey over the past 50 days as we connected with you through our 50 Days of Integrity campaign. Throughout this series, we have explored critical issues—from corruption trends to the importance of International Anti-Corruption Day—aimed at fostering awareness and accountability. As we wrap up this series, it’s worth pausing to reflect on a key question at the heart of our discussions: What exactly is “corrupt conduct,” and when does ICAC have the authority to act?

The post Understanding Corrupt Conduct and ICAC’s Jurisdiction appeared first on Post Courier.
item.source:markdown:
![](https://www.postcourier.com.pg/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/ICAC-11.png?w=1024)
It has been an inspiring and rewarding journey over the past 50 days as we connected with you through our 50 Days of Integrity campaign. Throughout this series, we have explored critical issues—from corruption trends to the importance of International Anti-Corruption Day—aimed at fostering awareness and accountability. As we wrap up this series, it’s worth pausing to reflect on a key question at the heart of our discussions: What exactly is “corrupt conduct,” and when does ICAC have the authority to act?

item.title: ‘No by-election after June’
item.description:
THERE will be no by-elections after June next year, acting Electoral Commissioner Margaret Vagi said.

Ms Vagi said if there are going to be any by-elections, then it must be done before June, as no by-elections should be conducted 12 months before the National General Elections.

item.title: Why are our rural children still searching for books?
item.description:
Last Friday, we ran a heartwarming story of a young girl and her desperate search for a book to read. Her name is Shenien Tyson, a bright 10-year-old who lives in the mountains of Fergusson Island in Milne Bay province.

The closest village is Sebutuia, where there is a school, where she completed grade 4 this year.

item.title: 2026 Teacher of the Year Banquet celebrates excellence in Education
item.description:
Source: ASG press release

Pago Pago, AMERICAN SAMOA — (December 16, 2025) A festive evening of celebration was held in Utulei to honor outstanding educators across the territory during the 2026 Teacher of the Year Banquet, attended by Governor Pulaali’i Nikolao Pula and First Lady Dr. Lois Pula.

The evening opened with a blessing by Father Pio Afu, setting a reverent and appreciative tone for a night dedicated to recognizing the service, commitment, and impact of teachers throughout American Samoa. Honorary guests included Department of Education Director Maefau Dr. Mary Lauagaia Taufete’e, Territorial Teacher of 2024-2025 Mikaela Saelua, along with Department of Education leaders, dedicated staff, and teachers from across the territory.

Governor Pulaali’i delivered remarks honoring educators for their vital role in shaping the future of the territory’s youth. Addressing teachers directly, the Governor emphasized the significance of their work, stating that, “Each of you carries a responsibility that is both powerful and deeply meaningful”.

He further expressed his appreciation, adding, “thank you for your time, talent, and sacrifice. And most importantly, thank you for giving our students the tools they need to shape their futures”.

He concluded by highlighting the importance of continued support for educators and the Department of Education, noting that when teachers are strengthened, generations to come are strengthened as well.

The ceremony recognized the following Teachers of the Year:

● Latalata Samuelu

● Jardian Mamea

● Otila Histake

● Joshlyn Ulimasao

● Lomialagi Tauiliili

● Itumalo Tufi

School Teacher of the Year:

● Filemoni Lauilefue

Teacher of the Year Finalists:

● Matasaua Pefu

● Edison Padaca

● Mafi Ioapo

The highlight of the evening was the recognition of the 2026 Territorial Teacher of the Year, Mr. Elisaia Mailo of Tafuna High School.

In his remarks, Mr. Mailo expressed his sincerest gratitude to all who played a role in this achievement, emphasizing that the honor was the result of a collective effort. He credited the guidance of his peers and leaders, as well as the encouragement and support of his family, for helping him achieve this milestone.

(Source: ASG_DOE)

[Editor’s Note: Samoa News should point out that the 2026 TTOY celebration comes at a time when Departments of Education are facing possible deep federal funding cuts, as the Trump Administration pushes to shut the USDOE down — opting instead to provide tuition vouchers to be used for private schools, religious or secular. ra]

Section: 
Local News
Tags: 
2026 TTOY Banquet
item.source:markdown:
[![Governor Pulaali’i Nikolao Pula](https://www.samoanews.com/sites/default/files/styles/slideshow/public/field/image/ttoy-banquet-image-2.jpg_copy.jpg?itok=v9oMgXH-)](https://www.samoanews.com/sites/default/files/styles/article_normal_image/public/field/image/ttoy-banquet-image-2.jpg_copy.jpg?itok=13U5BjAO)

item.title: Catholic parishioners celebrate 25 years of priesthood for Rev. Andrew Moses
item.description:
Catholic parishioners from across the Daru-Kiunga Diocese gathered at Bolivip Mission Station in the Olsobip Rural LLG, North Fly District, to celebrate the 25th anniversary (Silver Jubilee) of priesthood of Rev. Andrew Moses, DIO and feast day of St. Andrew’s Parish Bolivip. 

Faithful from St Gerard Parish (Kiunga), St. Brigid Parish (Kiunga), St Bertila Parish (Iowara), St John Parish (Matkomnae), Sacred Heart Parish (Tarakbits), Our Lady of Papua Parish (Kungim), Our Lady of the Star Mountains Parish (Tabubil), and St Andrew’s Parish (Bolivip) will be attending the Silver Jubilee celebration.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Catholic parishioners celebrate 25 years of priesthood for Rev. Andrew Moses appeared first on Post Courier.

Faithful from St Gerard Parish (Kiunga), St. Brigid Parish (Kiunga), St Bertila Parish (Iowara), St John Parish (Matkomnae), Sacred Heart Parish (Tarakbits), Our Lady of Papua Parish (Kungim), Our Lady of the Star Mountains Parish (Tabubil), and St Andrew’s Parish (Bolivip) will be attending the Silver Jubilee celebration.

item.title: Deloitte PNG employee attends global youth summit
item.description:
A YOUNG professional from Deloitte Papua New Guinea has returned home inspired after attending the One Young World Summit in Munich, Germany.

One Young World is an annual global forum that brings together young leaders from more than 190 countries to discuss solutions to global challenges, supported by corporate partners and world-renowned counsellors. Deloitte is a long-standing global partner of the initiative.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

item.title: Water PNG address Lae water equipment outage
item.description:
The CEO of Water PNG Limited, James Young, has advised that critical bore pumping equipment has failed in Lae resulting in temporary water rationing, that is being rectified by the delivery of replacement components as soon as is possible.

Mr. Young said the outage is frustrating and he wants the public to be aware of what they can do to reduce impact on their lives, and what is being done to rectify the problem.

item.title: The 2nd Year Nyanam Dart Tournament kicks off today in Aitape in West Sepik
item.description:
The annual Nyanam Civil Engineering PNG Limited Dart Tournament for 2025 kicks off today with a motorcade convoy of last year's defending champions Team Maruja around Aitape Urban returning the tournament cup back to the competition arena.

Despite rain showers in the morning, the organizing committee successfully officiated the opening ceremony and began games.

item.title: Waiakea subdivision bill to go to full council
item.description: The County Council’s Committee on Legislative Approvals and Acquisitions on Tuesday voted to forward a favorable recommendation to the full council for a zoning change allowing an applicant to subdivide a 4.4-acre property near the Hilo Municipal Golf Course into 14 house lots and a road.

item.title: Trump’s top aide acknowledges ‘score settling’ behind prosecutions
item.description: WASHINGTON — President Donald Trump’s chief of staff said she tried to get him to end his “score settling” against political enemies after 90 days in office, but acknowledged that the administration’s still ongoing push for prosecutions has been fueled in part by the president’s desire for retribution.
item.source:markdown: WASHINGTON — President Donald Trump’s chief of staff said she tried to get him to end his “score settling” against political enemies after 90 days in office, but acknowledged that the administration’s still ongoing push for prosecutions has been fueled in part by the president’s desire for retribution.

item.title: Unemployment rate rises, a warning sign for the US economy
item.description: The unemployment rate rose to a four-year high in November, a warning sign for the health of a labor market strained by the Trump administration’s cuts to the federal workforce and tariffs that have raised the cost of doing business.
item.source:markdown: The unemployment rate rose to a four-year high in November, a warning sign for the health of a labor market strained by the Trump administration’s cuts to the federal workforce and tariffs that have raised the cost of doing business.

item.title: Filmmaker Rob Reiner’s son faces murder charges in parents’ slaying, prosecutors say
item.description: LOS ANGELES — Prosecutors said they planned to file murder charges on Tuesday against the younger son of Hollywood filmmaker and political activist Rob Reiner, accusing him of using a knife to kill his parents in their Los Angeles home over the weekend.
item.source:markdown: LOS ANGELES — Prosecutors said they planned to file murder charges on Tuesday against the younger son of Hollywood filmmaker and political activist Rob Reiner, accusing him of using a knife to kill his parents in their Los Angeles home over the weekend.

item.title: Trump orders blockade of sanctioned oil tankers leaving, entering Venezuela
item.description: WASHINGTON — President Donald Trump ordered on Tuesday a “blockade” of all sanctioned oil tankers entering and leaving Venezuela, in Washington’s latest move to increase pressure on Nicolas Maduro’s government, targeting its main source of income.
item.source:markdown: WASHINGTON — President Donald Trump ordered on Tuesday a “blockade” of all sanctioned oil tankers entering and leaving Venezuela, in Washington’s latest move to increase pressure on Nicolas Maduro’s government, targeting its main source of income.

item.description: WASHINGTON — President Donald Trump’s approval rating slipped in recent days to nearly its lowest level of his current term as voters from his Republican Party soured on his handling of the economy, according to a new Reuters/Ipsos poll.

item.title: JD Vance asks for patience in Pennsylvania on US cost of living

item.title: Man, couple who died trying to stop Bondi Beach attackers praised for heroic efforts
item.description: SYDNEY — While a Sydney shopowner is being hailed as a hero after disarming one of the gunmen shooting at a Jewish holiday event at Sydney’s Bondi Beach, a couple and another man who died after physically confronting the attackers are also being remembered for their heroic efforts to save those around them.

item.title: Sydney gunmen were motivated by Islamic State, Australia’s leader says
item.description: SYDNEY — The attack on a Jewish celebration in Sydney was motivated by “Islamic State ideology,” Australia’s prime minister said Tuesday as investigators probed whether a visit to the southern Philippines last month by the two suspected gunmen had any connection to the mass shooting.
item.source:markdown: SYDNEY — The attack on a Jewish celebration in Sydney was motivated by “Islamic State ideology,” Australia’s prime minister said Tuesday as investigators probed whether a visit to the southern Philippines last month by the two suspected gunmen had any connection to the mass shooting.

item.title: Trump adds seven countries, including Syria, to full travel ban list
item.description: WASHINGTON — U.S. President Donald Trump on Tuesday expanded a list of countries subject to a full travel ban, prohibiting citizens from an additional seven countries, including Syria, from entering the United States.
item.source:markdown: WASHINGTON — U.S. President Donald Trump on Tuesday expanded a list of countries subject to a full travel ban, prohibiting citizens from an additional seven countries, including Syria, from entering the United States.

item.title: US will not release full Venezuela boat strike video, Hegseth says
item.description: WASHINGTON — U.S. Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth said on Tuesday there are no plans to release the full unedited video of the September 2 strikes on a suspected drug trafficking boat in the Caribbean that fueled concerns about the Trump administration’s plans for Venezuela. Hegseth and Secretary of State Marco Rubio conducted briefings on Tuesday for every member of the Senate and House of Representatives, responding to lawmakers’ demands for more information about a 3-1/2-month campaign of more than 20 strikes against boats in the Caribbean and Pacific that have killed more than 80 people. On Monday, the U.S. military struck three vessels in the Pacific, killing eight people.
item.source:markdown: WASHINGTON — U.S. Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth said on Tuesday there are no plans to release the full unedited video of the September 2 strikes on a suspected drug trafficking boat in the Caribbean that fueled concerns about the Trump administration’s plans for Venezuela. Hegseth and Secretary of State Marco Rubio conducted briefings on Tuesday for every member of the Senate and House of Representatives, responding to lawmakers’ demands for more information about a 3-1/2-month campaign of more than 20 strikes against boats in the Caribbean and Pacific that have killed more than 80 people. On Monday, the U.S. military struck three vessels in the Pacific, killing eight people.

item.title: Judge says he is unlikely to immediately halt Trump’s $300 million White House ballroom project
item.description: WASHINGTON — A federal judge in Washington said on Tuesday that he was not inclined to order the Trump administration to immediately halt work on a $300 million White House ballroom on the site of the demolished East Wing while hearing a lawsuit alleging the project abuses presidential power.
item.source:markdown: WASHINGTON — A federal judge in Washington said on Tuesday that he was not inclined to order the Trump administration to immediately halt work on a $300 million White House ballroom on the site of the demolished East Wing while hearing a lawsuit alleging the project abuses presidential power.

item.title: Authorities still trying to identify Brown University gunman three days into manhunt
item.description: Authorities on Tuesday once again asked members of the public for help identifying the suspected gunman who killed two Brown University students in a classroom over the weekend, as the manhunt stretched past 72 hours and residents remained on edge.

item.title: Obituaries for December 17
item.description: Octavia Amante Muraoka, 87, of Kailua-Kona died Nov. 10 at Kona Community Hospital. She was a laundry valet for Four Seasons Hualalai Resort and worked for Ben Franklin and the former Kona Surf Resort. Visitation 9:30-10 a.m., Saturday, Jan. 3, at Kona Faith Center in Captain Cook Service at 10 a.m. Casual attire. Survived by son, Mario (Daphne) Hooper; daughters, Charlyn DeMello and Jasmine (John) Staup of Honalo; sisters, Olivia Sasada of Kailua-Kona and Judith DeMello of Holualoa; seven grandchildren, 14 great-grandchildren and a great-great grandchild; nieces, nephews, cousins and in-laws. Arrangements by Dodo Mortuary.

item.title: Air Niugini fleet restores to full strength ahead of Christmas Peak
item.description:
Air Niugini has successfully restored its flight operations to full capacity just days before the Christmas peak, following the return of four previously grounded aircraft and the commissioning of its newest aircraft.

Air Niugini’s Officer In Charge, Captain Samiu Taufa, has confirmed flight operations have returned to strength with the four aircraft that had been out of service last week returning to service over the weekend.

item.title: Nambawan Super Board appoints incoming CEO
item.description:
The Nambawan Super Limited has announced that its Trustee Board of Directors appointed the company’s incoming Chief Executive Officer (CEO), Mr Lachlan Baird, today and will be effectively be in office as of January 1st, 2026.

Incoming CEO Lachlan Baird brings over 30 years of experience in the superannuation, investment and financial sectors to Nambawan Super. He previously served as Chief Executive Officer of Prime Super, a broad-based independent superannuation fund with circa AU$7 billion in assets.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post Nambawan Super Board appoints incoming CEO appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: Balimo College produces first cohort of home-grown teachers
item.description:
The Balimo College, is K72 million investment funded by the Sustainable Development Programme (SDP) has celebrated a significant milestone yesterday with a total of 26 graduate students who successfully attained their Bachelor of Education in Primary Teaching, boosting efforts to address teacher shortages in Western Province.

These graduates previously completed the Diploma of Primary Teaching in
March this year and successfully met the requirements to progress onto completing
their bachelor qualification.

item.title: CCAC members work together on elections integrity
item.description:
In an effort to strengthen partnership with community actors, the Community Coalition Against Corruption (CCAC) convened a session on the November 20, 2025 in Port Moresby.

CCAC Members including, Transparency International PNG (TIPNG), the Advancing PNG: Women’s Leadership Network (APNGWLN), Caritas PNG, and the PNG Council of Churches (PNGCC) presented at an information session with women leaders in PNG on Election Integrity.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post CCAC members work together on elections integrity appeared first on Post Courier.

![](https://www.postcourier.com.pg/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-17-165257.jpg?w=887)
In an effort to strengthen partnership with community actors, the Community Coalition Against Corruption (CCAC) convened a session on the November 20, 2025 in Port Moresby.
CCAC Members including, Transparency International PNG (TIPNG), the Advancing PNG: Women’s Leadership Network (APNGWLN), Caritas PNG, and the PNG Council of Churches (PNGCC) presented at an information session with women leaders in PNG on Election Integrity.
To access this post, you must purchase [Web](https://www.postcourier.com.pg/product/web/) or [Web & eBook](https://www.postcourier.com.pg/product/web-ebook/).

item.title: East Sepik Cocoa Farmers built new bridge
item.description:
A remote community in the Greater Sepik region of Papua New Guinea has demonstrated a clear example of what becomes possible when local initiative is met with supportive partnership.

With support from the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) and the International Labour Organization (ILO) through the EU-STREIT PNG Programme, Hambini village, with about 9,000 people in Drekikier, East Sepik Province, has recently replaced an old, damaged and impassable log bridge with a permanent bridge made of steel, concrete and timber.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post East Sepik Cocoa Farmers built new bridge appeared first on Post Courier.

item.title: PNG Power Kokopo clears lines for festive season
item.description:
PNG Power Limited Kokopo office has cleared natural vegetation encroaching on power lines as it works hard to ensure communities enjoy uninterrupted electricity during the festive season.

The PPL Kokopo office has partnered with low–risk inmates from Kerevat CIS to carry out major line–clearance work along the main 22kV feeder lines and the 66kV transmission network—the essential routes that deliver electricity to homes and communities.

To access this post, you must purchase Web or Web & eBook.

The post PNG Power Kokopo clears lines for festive season appeared first on Post Courier.

item.description:

We are informed service providers to the prisons around the country are refusing to provide rations to the prisons because they are owed some K5 million. They have been kept waiting for the last few months.

item.title: Manalos Aviation establishes clinic to improve survival of airlifted patients
item.description:
Manalos Aviation’s Mountain Area Medical Airlift Foundation is strengthening emergency medical response in Morobe Province by constructing a health clinic within its helipad facility in Lae to provide immediate care to patients flown in from remote areas.

Commercial and Compliance Manager, Nellie Tumai, said the initiative was driven by the need to save lives through timely medical intervention.

item.title: Stop Work order defied: CEPA to impound equipment at Wau-Bulolo National Park
item.description:
The Conservation & Environment Protection Authority (CEPA) will confiscate all alluvial machinery and impound them for non-compliance to stop work notice issued to Asian alluvial mining operator at McAdams National Park, amidst Wau-Bulolo-Watut valley.

The continuous illegal operations forced Manki inhabitants to devise a plan to take the law upon themselves to move in to remove Asian alluvial miner and illegal settlers defying CEPA instructions.
